Old Sun's Indian Residential School

We find it necessary to send back the September Quarterly Return, although you have evidently reviewed it as you have signed the Return.

It is noted that grant for the full quarter has been requested for Pupil 242 - Edward Wolfchild and Pupil 263 - George Turning Robe. Dear Dr. Westgate:

I am enclosing you the account which was under discussion when you were on your last visit to us. After going into the matter carefully with the contractor, Mr. W.T. Scott, it was found that in order to turn the present study into a suitable kitchen would have cost him around $125.00, whereas this arrangement would have been a source of danger from fire. A new chimney for the kitchen fire would have had to be constructed, and entrance made with porchway into the study, etc. Furthermore as has already been pointed out no suitable entrance into the basement could be located other than an outside one, which would have been useless or at least a great hardship especially during the winter months.

The present kitchen as you know is a mere kitchenette as it covers the stairway into the basement, as well as serving as a kitchen. The present arrangement on the whole cost the Department about the same as any other suggested arrangement, if any had been forthcoming at the time, and furthermore serves the purpose with greater convenience and safety.

Considering everything, I feel that the Indian Department will not be out of pocket in meeting the enclosed account as a somewhat similar amount would have had to be spent in any case.

Regretting that this unnecessary trouble is being given you,

I remain,

Dear Mr. Gooderham:

One of our Pressure Tanks sprung a leak on Wednesday night last. I had Mr. Michael out to examine it, and we find that it is the old tank which has gone under water. It is eaten right through and it is impossible, I believe, to fix it in its present narrow confines. We had it disconnected from the new tank which was placed here five years ago, but this will only meet an emergency condition as we shall have to pump very constantly. It will be necessary to look into this matter as soon as possible. Mr. Michael and I have gone into the matter very closely and can give you a report as to what would be best to do under the circumstances.

Also our pump has been inspected and as the head has not been out since it was placed here about five years ago, it will be absolutely necessary to have this seen to, as well as a new belt is required. This will cost roughly about $50.00.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report for the month of November 1927.

SCHOOLS

At Crowfoot school threshing was completed on the 5th. An inspection of fire equipment was made by Mr. Duncan Clark, Assistant Agent, for the writer and Pyrene extinguishers have been refilled and placed in convenient places in the school. The Principal reports that the hose is in order and that drill carried out. All the pupils were well and three of the older girls were married this month.

At Old Suns two inspections were made. Considerable improvement was noted in interior economy. One of the pressure tanks is pitted and leaking badly. It cannot be repaired, I understand and replacement will be matter for consideration by the Department. One tank is now serving all purposes and should do for the winter months if the pressure is kept up continually.

G. H. Gooderham,
Agent.

Sir,

In his report for the month of November Mr. G. H. Goderham referred to the poor condition of one of the pressure tanks in the Old Sams school and, while stating that this matter would need to be brought to the attention of the Department, thought that the other remaining pressure tank would be sufficient to meet requirements until the spring.

I asked him for further information and I am now in receipt of a letter from Mr. Lewis, who is in charge during Mr. Goderham's absence, stating that these tanks are in the ground with a solid concrete floor above, with access to them through a man-hole in the floor. He adds, presumably upon information given him by a local plumber, that the cost of taking up this floor and replacing the tank would be considerable and suggests that a cheaper method would be to install a new 2100 gal. tank in the basement of the school at a cost in the neighborhood of $1,000.00. I have not verified these figures, but as a new 2100 gal. tank would cost in Winnipeg approximately $100.00, the remaining $900.00 seems a more than sufficient sum to transport it to Gleichen and install it. It is suggested that in case of fire the present water supply would be inadequate with the use of only one pressure tank and he also states that those now in use are of a capacity of 1100 gal. each. However, I think the Department will agree with me that the existing tank

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a short report on the Crowfoot and Old Sun's Indian Residential Schools in the Blackfoot Agency.

There is nothing in the report regarding the Crowfoot School which requires any attention. The matter of fire escapes leading from the front dormitories has been dealt with by supplying main ladders.

You will note the Inspector states that the situation at Old Sun's was about as usual. We have had some correspondence with you regarding the replacing of one of the pressure tanks at this institution. The only thing that can be done is to put in a new tank in the Spring. I understand the cost of this will be about $1000.00.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
At the Old Sun's School I found things in general about as usual. The children appeared well but the school was not a bit tidier than it usually is. I also checked up the fire fighting apparatus here and found everything in good order. Fire drill is carried on and everything in the way of equipment has been supplied and every precaution is taken to guard against fire. The only thing that is lacking is an adequate supply of water. This, of course, would have nothing to do with getting the children safely out of the building in case of fire, and while the building might burn down owing to a shortage of water it would not prevent the children being saved. You have had some correspondence with Mr. Lewis regarding the water supply and I beg to say that the water is pumped from a well into two pressure tanks. These tanks are in a cement basement under the basement proper and are covered all around with cement, the only access to them being through a manhole. One of the tanks was new when the school was remodeled, and the other one was old. The old tank has become worn out through rust and corrosion and it does not appear practicable to me to tear up the basement and break up the cement in order to hoist this tank up. The more satisfactory solution would be to get a 2500-gallon tank and there is a room in the basement only a few feet from the well where it could be placed. Some wall would have to be taken down in order to get it in but this would entail a much smaller cost than the other plan. This matter, however, can wait until Spring comes, as I see no urgent need for it.

OLD SUN SCHOOL BURNED

Building on Indian Reserve—All Children Safe

Gleichen, Alta., June 27 — Fire breaking out in the basement of Old Sun school, Blackfoot Reserve, one mile south of Gleichen, last night, destroyed the building.

During the late evening smoke was noticed coming from the basement room. Already half of the children had gone to bed, but all were brought to safety by means of the exit, according to rules of the fire drill which had been practiced by the staff and children. It is believed that the fire was started by spontaneous combustion and spread rapidly.

The building, being owned by the Indian Department of the Federal Government, no insurance was carried.

All the heavy clothing for the children from the old school, which was donated by the ladies of the Toronto diocese of the Anglican Church, was destroyed.

June 27, 1928

Dear Sir:

In confirmation of my wire of even date, Old Sun School is burned to charred ruins from a fire which seemed to originate in a combination dairy and storage cellar last evening. I am of the opinion that the fire was spontaneous combustion of raffia and other stuff which was stored in this room. Fire fighters with chemical engines were rushed from Gleichen but it was nearly impossible to get at this room as it was originally a root-cellar with only one entrance from the inside of the building. The smoke was intense and the water supply very limited and the fire got into the wood-work of the main structure and was soon out of control. An attempt was made to save the front of the building by setting off dynamite in the middle area. This was not successful.

All children and staff were out of the building and are safe & sound. The children were sent home with their parents during the night and will remain there for the present as holidays are practically at hand.

The Principal's house is intact but Mr. Gibney suffered loss by damage to furnishings which were moved out. The water supply & electric energy for the house and barn was cut off but the Power Company will no doubt remedy this shortly.

I have turned over the vacant house half a mile North of the school for the use of the Farm Instructor and others of the staff and their effects are being moved today.

Practically nothing of value was salvaged and machinery in the basement is junk now. Everything in our power was done to stop the fire the origin of which is conjecture. Fortunately, good fire drill prevented panic and no pupils or members of the staff suffered except myself from sleep and excitement. I have reported the fire as required under Provincial regulations.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

The Principal of the Old Sun School has just directed my attention to the urgent need of a residence for the Farm Instructor at this School, and I am wondering if it would be possible for your Department to take steps to have this building provided immediately.

The Farm Instructor is occupying at present a house loaned by the Blackfoot Agency, and situated about half a mile away from the site of the old School. The Farm Instructor is finding this, at the busy season of the year, very inconvenient, and the Principal feels that it will not only be inconvenient to him during the winter months, but a hardship as well, if he is obliged to carry on his work at this distance. The building he is occupying has no kitchen range, and he and his wife are using an oil stove of their own. If they must live there during the coming winter it will take, I understand, a good deal of coal to keep the building heated.

I am under the impression that there was an appropriation for a Principal's residence at this School this year, and although the destruction of the main school building by fire has created unexpected problems in this connection, I am of the opinion that the Farm Instructor's residence should be provided forthwith if at all possible. I have not seen the plan of the one being constructed at St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve, but it seems to me that the building that will suit in one place would do equally well in the other.
I commend this matter to your prompt and sympathetic consideration, and remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Re- Proposed New School to replace Old Sun's School
on Blackfoot Reserve at Gleichen, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Orr:

In further reply to your letter of the 6th instant with
reference to the proposed school to take the place of the building
destroyed by fire, I am now able to submit the following Report.

I proceeded to Gleichen by the early train on the 14th
instant, and spent all of that day, and till noon of the following
day, in gathering data and forming impressions, along the lines
mentioned in your letter of instructions.

I was joined by the Indian Agent, Mr. Geo. H. Gooderham,
who rendered me every possible assistance, and together we proceeded
to the ruins of the old building where the present school, the Rev. F.M.
Ross Gibney came to us from the Indian church nearby where he was
holding day classes. Your letter to me was read by both gentlemen, so
that it would be clearly understood on what lines our co-operation
was being invited.

The fire certainly made a clean sweep of the former
building, every scrap of combustible material having been licked up,
and the ruined wreckage are complete. The scarred and cracked
concrete walls enclose a mass of tangled and twisted iron and steel,
warped I beams, ruined plumbing fixtures, laundry equipment, etc., in
a seemingly inextricable mass. It is doubtful if anything remains
that could safely be used again in the new building, but even these will
have lost their original temper, and it would be undesirable to use
any of them again except perhaps in unimportant outbuildings. The
laundry boiler seemed to be the only solitary exception, having been
placed in a concrete chamber of its own it seemed to have been more
or less protected from the general fire, and an examination by a
boiler inspector might result in this article being pronounced fit
for further service.

With regard to the best means of filling in the old excavation,
I should advise that this work be made part of the general contract
for the new building, and that the contractor tendering be allowed
possession of the existing wreckage. He will then carefully examine
and appraise the ruins, and if he find anything there of value to
him for use elsewhere, he will reduce his tender accordingly,
and in this way the Department also receive credit for whatever may
be salvaged from the ruin before being filled in. The contractor
would scarcely omit this opportunity of reducing his tender (if any
salvage be possible), nor do I will know that his competitor might
otherwise undertake him and thus capture the contract. I think therefore,
the Specifications should call for the filling in of the existing
excavation as part of the general contract; and that the old concrete
walls be broken off to a line at least two feet below the present grade;
and that the contractor be allowed possession of the debris. The portions
of the concrete walls broken off would, of course, be well buried in
the filling of the old excavation. I fully agree with you that it would
be unwise to rebuild on the site of the former building.

There is also an old foundation, and small excavation, from an old
schoolhouse adjacent to the proposed site of the new building, which
will be in the line of future driveway, and this should also be broken
up and levelled. This is comparatively a very small matter, but might
be included too in the general contract.
Regarding the site of the proposed new building, we gave very careful consideration to this important matter. For obvious reasons we could not place the building on its former site; nor could we go in front of the old site without encroaching on the roadway, and also such a position would be in a bad dust area. We could not place the school at the rear of the old site because of the barn and buildings, root-house, etc., now located there. After examining various alternative sites, we then gave attention to a site which had previously been favourably regarded and tentatively agreed upon by Mr. Gooderham and Mr. Honey. This favoured site has an east exposure, and will face the main cross-country highway about half a mile distant, and will be clearly visible from farms approaching from the east. I could find no objection to this site, and my own opinion confirmed the judgment of the local officials that this is the best site available in that vicinity. We felt there was no use going too far afield in quest of sites because of increasing distance from valuable outbuildings and farm operations.

This proposed site is quite close to the position of the former school, and equally convenient to the barn and other farm buildings. I took levels on the site itself, and found only 26 feet difference between the high and low extremes. The surrounding land is practically level, but with a slight slope away to the east, which increases until a declivity is reached about 100 yards away from the proposed front of the building. Across the road to the north the land also falls away, and it is in this direction that the sewage disposal from the former building would find an outlet. I enclose a rough sketch which may enable you better to understand the relative position of the proposed new site. Of course, in plotting the proposed new building, I could only do so with approximate correctness, as I have not exact knowledge of the size of the new building.

With regard to sewage disposal, I did not have time to run levels, but I am convinced from superficial observations that there will be sufficient fall for our purpose. The former building with its deep basement and deeper drains, had none too much fall, and the sewer was sluggish, but with the much shallower basement proposed for the new building, the conditions in the matter of fall will be much more favourable, and there is no doubt in my mind but that we can get by. The sewage disposal from the new school will be diverted into the existing sewage disposal system, provided that on examination the septic tank and disposal field are found to be suitable and in good condition. In all events the sewage will have to be taken in the same direction.

Another point to which we gave consideration was that of the school well. The drilled well in the old building was most satisfactory, giving excellent water which had never been pumped. The situation now is in the midst of the general ruin, and it would be rather difficult to build a new well-house there and operate it separately. It was thought advisable to drill a new well to come within what is shown on the Lytton plan as the "Lighting Room," so that the pumping plant might be placed in a corresponding place in the proposed new building. The purpose of redesigning this "Lighting Room" is to use it as Dairy Room, as I shall explain presently. In the unlikely event of the drilling failing to get a good water supply, then we would be compelled to utilize the well used before, in which event a "Pump House" would be necessary directly over the original well. The location of a well to serve the new building would be adjacent to the present well, perhaps about 50 feet distant, so it is altogether likely we would tap the same water reservoir below.

With regard to the best method of storing water for use throughout the building, and to obtain sufficient pressure and volume, I believe a tower and elevated tank would be the most satisfactory. In anticipation of this requirement I shall obtain data on this subject, and write again at an early date. In this connection I might say that there is now on hand at Gleichen a new pressure tank that
was procured by the Department for Old Sun's School, but Mr. Gooderham informs me that this tank is needed to augment the storage capacity of the water system which supplies their Indian Hospital and the Agency residences, and therefore this new tank need not be a factor in planning a water system for the new school building.

Now, with regard to the building itself, I had with me the floor plans of the Lytton School, and they were carefully examined by Mr. Gooderham, Rev. and Mrs. Gibney, and myself, with a view to determining in what respects the Lytton building seemed suitable and what alterations seemed desirable, and the suggestions which follow are respectfully offered for your kind consideration.

1. Principal's Residence exactly as shown, except to be changed to the other end of the school. It will then be next to the driveway, and will give observation of the approach to the school.

2. Boys and girls' quarters to be reversed so that the girls will occupy the side of the building next to the Principal's residence.

3. It is proposed to omit the "Second Floor" shown in the Lytton plan. The wings and centre building to remain the same size as shown. The lavatory, baths, toilets, etc., could be reduced to the needs of 90 children.

4. The rear extension from main building could be reduced in size to serve 90 children and Staff.

5. One toilet opposite laundry entrance will suffice.

6. Laundry can share in reduction of rear extension.

7. Lighting Room to be retained, but to be used as Dairy and Pump Room. An outside entrance is desired. In the proposed position of the new building this room will be the nearest point to the Barn. It might be reduced one third in size.

8. Coal Cellar to be retained, but to have reinforced concrete roof at grade level, with manhole opening and cover.

9. Pantry to be equipped with Frigidaire.

10. Room shown as "Stores" adjoining Boiler Room to be changed to Engineer's Room, and to have wash-basin with H & C water.

11. Room shown as "Janitor's Room" in Basement to be used for "Stores".

12. Domestic Coal Chute and Bin serving Kitchen to be retained.

13. Boys' and Girls' quarters on the Ground and First Floors will be reversed as well as in the Basement.

14. It is requested that the Sewing Room and Class Room on Girls' Side be converted into one room instead of two as shown, the blackboard to be placed on the wall adjoining Stairway.

15. The Principal requests that the Corridor to the Residence be enclosed by accordion doors similar to St. Paul's School, so that the two class-rooms may be thrown into one large auditorium for concerts and other entertainments.

16. The arrangement of Boys' Class Rooms and Study to be retained.

17. The Class Room shown in centre main building to be converted into a Guests' Bed Room, although this might be reduced in size. The space thus saved might be utilized to form an inner Principal's Office next to the main office, some space being also taken from the main office for this purpose.

18. The Assembly Hall to share in reduction in size or elimination from main building. The Principal desires that the School be similar to the arrangement at St. P...
19. It is desired that a "clothing room" be built in the centre of the Dormitories,—that is, one clothing room in each wing to serve both the Dormitories adjoining. These Clothing Rooms might be about 8' x 24' in size, with a doorway from each Dormitory to be kept under lock and key. Open lockers, with drawer below and hat-shelf above, might be built around the walls of this room. The Principal reports much trouble from lockers accessible to the children, whereas under the proposed arrangement the children will not have access to the lockers except when under direct supervision.

20. The Principal desires an observation window to be placed in the walls of the Staff Rooms adjoining large Dormitories, if feasible.

21. Night Lights are desired in Dormitories.

22. The room shown as "Drugs and Stores" to be included with the Staff Room to the right, and both rooms thrown into one large room to receive the bales of clothing, etc., which come annually in large quantities. Having an Indian Hospital near at hand it was not considered necessary to retain a room for Drugs.

23. In view of the suggestion that the "Second Floor" shown in the Lytton plans be omitted, it is considered advisable to retain the Infirmarys as extra Dormitories should they be shown in the final plans. Inadequate, the Principal thinks these rooms may not be needed as infirmaries because of the availability of the Indian Hospital, but he thinks they may be needed in case of the space in the Dormitories on the one floor being overcrowded, in which event he would assign the older pupils to these rooms.

24. If equally economical, and otherwise suitable, it is desired that the new building have a gable roof instead of a flat roof. If a gable roof be provided, it is desired that a Spire be omitted. Owing to excessive winds and driving storms, spires have given trouble, and are difficult to keep weather-proof. Instead of a Spire, the Principal requests that a small finial with Cross be placed over the central gable above the school entrance.

25. The Principal requests that a Farm Instructor's Residence be provided apart from the school building, and that this be erected in the near future. The present Farm Instructor is proving an invaluable employee, and is bringing the school farm into excellent productivity and efficiency.

26. The Residence now being occupied by the Reverend Principal and his family might well be demolished when the living quarters in the new building are ready. This building has already been moved twice, and is scarcely worth moving again. It is "ramshackle" in appearance, difficult to heat, extremely inconvenient in its interior arrangements, and would be altogether undesirable alongside a new, modern building. Its present situation is just off the proposed site of the new building. It is needed as a residence for the Principal and family until the new building is ready for occupation, and then I consider it will have served the past and present generations sufficiently, and might then be carefully taken down, and any materials of value could be used again in unimportant outbuildings, or otherwise disposed of.

27. The Principal requests that a stone name-plate, with inset lettering (or other suitable name-plate) be placed over the main entrance of the school.

I think the foregoing items include about all the suggestions that were thought of at our joint conference, and in respectfully submitting them for your kind consideration we recognize that there may be difficulties in the way of granting all the requests mentioned; or, for reasons for modifying them further, there has been a constant effort to avoid extravagance, and to ask only for those things which seem important for the efficient administration of the school, and for the health and comfort of the occupants.

Dear Sir:

During my visit to the Blackfoot Reserve last week, my attention was directed to the need of a Farmer's cottage in connection with the new building which it is expected your Department will provide during the coming summer to replace the Old Sun School. I undertook to bring this matter to your attention and I shall be obliged if you will give it your sympathetic consideration. Mr. Bates, the Farm Instructor is a very competent staff agent, and may be relied upon to place the farming activities in connection with this institution on a satisfactory basis. He should, however, have a cottage of his own detached from the main school building, and I beg to suggest that steps be taken at the earliest date possible to have this building erected.

When I visited the St. Paul's School a few days before proceeding to the Blackfoot Reserve, I went carefully over the Farmer's cottage which you have provided for this institution, and am of the opinion that a cottage built on the same plan and of the same dimensions and material would do very well for the Farm Instructor's residence at the Old Sun School.

I commend this request to your favourable consideration, and have the honour to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Orr:

With further reference to my letter of the 9th ultimo and your reply to the same on Jan. 14th, enclosing plans for the new School to replace the Old Sun School on the Blackfoot Reserve, I beg to state that during my recent visit to this Reserve I had an opportunity of discussing the whole situation with Mr. Gibney, the Principal of the old School, up until the time it was destroyed. Mr. Gibney showed me a copy of the memorandum which had been prepared by Mr. Gardner-Smith in consultation with himself, and also a copy of the suggestions which he himself was forwarding to you in connection with the proposed plans for the new School which he had examined. Beyond the suggestions made by Mr. Gibney, all of which I approve, I have only a few remarks to offer, and these are as follows:

1. A suitable garage is a necessity and should be built as part of the main School building in order that it may be heated from the central heating plant. A motor car is required summer and winter in connection with the School work all over the prairie provinces, and my recent visit to Southern Alberta when the weather was at times 50 below zero, convinced me that a heated garage is a necessity. The suggested location of this garage, as given by Mr. Gibney, appears to me to be suitable.

2. The Principal's residence should be large enough to include 4 bedrooms and a den or study. Owing to the dust-laden winds which prevail at times in Alberta, the glazed verandah off the living room of the Principal's
residence is very necessary, and I trust it may be provided, and have the sun porch above it as requested by the Principal, as well.

3. The plans do not make provision for an Indian room, and this is a very essential part of a residential school building.

4. A partition should be installed on the first floor so as to keep the two sides of the building separate.

5. I should like to suggest that this School be provided with spiral fire escapes instead of the ordinary ladder type which the younger children find it very difficult to use. So far as I know the spiral type has not been supplied to any Indian Residential School, and even though the cost might be greater than the ladder type, I am of the opinion that they are the safest and should be provided.

6. I have already addressed a separate communication to the Secretary with regard to the provision of a Farm Instructor's cottage. I have suggested that one built on the same plan and of the same material as the one provided at the St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve, would meet the needs of this institution. I see no reason why the erection of this building should not be taken in hand at once. The Farm Instructor who is a very efficient man, and who is at present living with his wife at a very considerable distance from the School site, should be comfortably and conveniently settled when the time comes to begin the Spring work, and I trust that prompt action may be taken in this matter.

7. It is understood by our Society that the new School will be built of brick.

I am holding the plans until our Commission have had an opportunity of examining them at their next meeting after which they will be returned to you.

Very kind regards,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant No. 104-15, informing me that Dr. Westgate had written to the Department urging that provision be made this year for a Farmer's cottage at the Old Sun's Indian Residential School. If it is the intention of the Department to rebuild this school there is no doubt a residence should be built for the Farmer, provided he is a married man. At some of our schools they are not particular whether the Farming Instructor is married or not, and in the past we have had a single man at the Old Sun's School so far as I know, but if Mr. Bate is a married man he should have a home. At the present time the Farmer is living in an Indian cottage about half a mile from the school, and this arrangement is not very satisfactory. A request for a cottage was made in September last by Dr. Westgate, and I informed the Department that there was no urgent need for it at the time. The cottage at the St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve cost in the neighborhood of $4000.00, and it would perhaps cost $4500.00 to build a similar cottage at Old Sun's, that is by putting in the plumbing, etc.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to my letter of Feb. 7th, and your reply to the same on Feb. 12th, 104-1-5, relative to the provision of a Farmer's residence at the Old Sun Indian Residential School, I beg to state that in a letter just received from the Rev. F. M. R. Gibney, Acting Principal of this School, and dated Feb. 19th, he informs me that the immediate need of this residence has been accentuated through the decision of your Department to have the house which is at present occupied by the Farm Instructor, fitted up as a residence for Dr. Windsor, the Medical Health Officer. Mr. Gibney's letter reads, in part, as follows:

"The Department may not be aware of the fact that we have the loan of one of their buildings, adjacent to No. 1 Government Farm Instructor's house, as a temporary home for our Farm Instr. Mr. Indian Agent Gooderham has just received communication from the Indian Department at Ottawa, requesting him to have this house renovated and wired for electric light for a residence for our Medical Health Officer, Dr. Windsor. This means that we shall be without a house for Mr. and Mrs. Bates. This leaves us in a quandary. Perhaps they could find a temporary above in town, but this would mean extra expense for somebody. I can see only one way out of our difficulty and that is the immediate erection of a suitable residence near the site of our proposed new school building. It would be well to point out this new development.

From the above information it is quite clear that some immediate action will have to be taken to provide accommodation for the Farm Instructor, and as a residence at the School will be
indispensable if we are to retain the services of the splendid man who now fills this position, I beg to request that a special effort be made to have this residence provided in the immediate future.

I commend this request to your careful and sympathetic consideration, and remain, Sir,

Dear Sir:

The Rev. F. M. R. Gibney, Principal of the Old Sun School, has directed the attention of our Commission to the need of a suitable shelter for the stock, in addition to the existing stock barn. He states that he has talked the matter over with Mr. Indian Agent Gooderham, who promised to take the matter up with your Department, and urge that a shelter about 75' long x 30' wide, with two 12' partitions under the same roof, be provided before next winter. He estimates the cost at approximately $385.00, this amount not including the cost of the partitions which should be made of planks, nor the cost of fencing.

In connection with this need, he also directs attention to the urgent need of more pasture land being attached to the school for the use of the school in the summer. Suitable pasture land is available, by extending the land already set apart for the use of the school, and I beg to recommend that you authorize Mr. Indian Agent Gooderham to arrange with the Principal for this extension.

The farming activities at this school are gradually developing into first class condition, and it will be an encouragement to the school management if the above needs, neither of which involve a very heavy expenditure, are provided. I commend them both to your sympathetic consideration and have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

TBRW/EMW

April 22/1929

I, the undersigned, W.T. Scott, do hereby agree to perform all labour in the erection of a Five-roomed bungalow at the Old Sun's Boarding School according to specifications as follows:

(1) Excavate a full-sized cellar to a depth of 5' and complete same to 7' clear in the basement. I will pour all concrete making and completing an 8' concrete wall and a concrete cellar floor, setting all cellar windows well above the ground.

(2) All carpenter work will be done in a workmanlike manner using material as supplied. Painting inside and outside where necessary, will also be done in a proper manner. If so desired, I will submit bills of material used from time to time and state that I am satisfied that the original bill of material is sufficient to complete the job.

(3) All work as herein set out will be done for my tender price of One thousand and fifty Dollars ($1050.00).

This work will be completed for the sum of $250.00.

(5) I guarantee that the workmanship on the entire building will be satisfactory to the Department of Indian Affairs.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 104-1-5, dated the 5th June, in connection with a request made by the Principal of the Old Sun's School, at Gleichen, to be provided with a shelter for cattle and more pasture accommodation.

I wish to inform you that I have had this matter investigated and I find that the School has about 35 head of cattle, and there is only room for 17 cows and some calves in the stable. As this institution is evidently depending considerably on their live stock, an outside shelter for the young stock is needed, and the cost of same would be somewhere in the neighborhood of what they estimate, namely $365.00, as this cost was figured out by the local carpenter. It might, of course, be built a little cheaper.

Extra pasturage is also required, and there is an abundance of land available adjoining the school land on the south. There is a fractional part of a section there which would meet the requirements for the present time. This would take between 2½ and 3 miles of fencing, which would cost in the neighborhood of $300.00 per material, and the work of erecting the fence might be done by the school.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa, July 9th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your 401-11A C.E. of the 2nd instant, relative to the providing of a shelter for the cattle and more pasture accommodation at the Old Sun's School.

Relative to the erection of a shelter, I have to say that you may arrange to have this accommodation for the cattle erected, and the cost should, if possible, not exceed the estimate furnished by the Principal, viz., $365, the work to be completed before the cold weather next Fall.

Regarding the extra pasturage, would it be necessary to get the Indian Band to set aside the fractional part of a section for school purposes? If so, you should endeavour to secure the consent of the Band, and, when this is obtained, you may incur an expenditure of approximately $300 in providing the fencing material required to fence same. It is thought that the work of erecting the fence might be done by the school authorities.

Certified accounts, in duplicate, covering any expenditure incurred for the above purposes should be forwarded in the usual manner.

OTTAWA.

Re- OLD SUN'S NEW RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Sir:

I duly received your telegrams of August 19th and 23rd, and your letter of the 26th, with reference to the erection of the new school on the Blackfoot Reserve. I note the contract has been awarded to the Wyndels Construction Company, of St. Boniface, Manitoba, and that I have been appointed Inspector of Construction. Please accept my thanks for this expression of the Department's continued confidence in me.

The contractor has not yet arrived at Gleichen, but is expected at any time, and it will be my aim to cooperate with him in the furtherance of the work and in the carrying out of the Plans and Specifications.

With regard to the old ruin, and the water supply for the new building, I shall be glad to receive some early intimation of the Department's intentions concerning these matters.

At the time of my leaving Lytton, B.C. there was still some painting to finish, pews to install, and a few small odds and ends to clean up, all of which was being supervised by the Reverend Principal as this work was not of sufficient importance to detain me there. I expect to receive the bills for these small services within the next few days, and shall then be in a position to render the complete accounts for all labour and materials, including a Statement of Cash Receipts and Disbursements, and a certified Statement of Balance at the Bank.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

INGLIS SUPREME BOILERS

SUPREME BOILERS Are constructed of flange steel plates with electrically welded seams, and are sold complete with base as a self contained unit ready for operation.

It is not necessary to build a special foundation as the boiler is carried on a cast iron base distributing the load over large area.

An ash pit not less than 6 inches deep should be excavated in floor or if this is impossible a high base should be ordered.

SUPREME BOILERS Are properly proportioned to give highest efficiency.

The boiler will carry the rated load quite easily and it is not necessary to choose a larger size than listed.

The area of grates governs the amount of coal which can be burned, the grate area can be increased to give proportionate extra boiler rating but efficiency will not be as good when proper ratio between grate and heating surface is reduced.

SUPREME BOILERS—Have an unusually large fire box, the crown of which is arched up to eliminate sediment pocket over the fire.

The return smoke box at front end of boiler is formed within the boiler and is surrounded by water. This makes a flush front boiler giving most freedom for firing.

All firing and flue door frames have flanges within the openings to protect welded seams from cold air blasts.

SUPREME BOILERS—Are designed for 30 pounds steam pressure and are approved in Ontario, Quebec, Alberta and Saskatchewan for this pressure, other provinces approve the boiler for 15 pounds which is the maximum they allow on welded boilers.

Special boilers are designed to suit conditions where standard boiler dimensions will not work in, provided that these conditions do not call for unbalanced design or sacrifice to boiler efficiency. Our engineering dept. will be pleased to give you information on proper settings for stokers or oil firing and any other advice on boilers or engineering in general.
INGLIS SUPREME
Steel Heating Boilers

SPECIFICATION

TYPE — INGLIS SUPREME Steel Heating Boilers are made in three types: Class S for low-pressure steam heating with a maximum of 30 pounds working pressure, Class W for hot-water heating installations for any head up to 100 ft. and Class L for water, low type for any head up to 100 ft.

Unless specially mentioned, these boilers will be equipped with shaking grates for hand firing and boiler mounted on cast-iron base. These boilers can be readily adapted for stokers or oil firing, in which case the grates are not supplied and a special base can be furnished to suit the application.

BOILER — The boiler is of flange steel construction, electrically welded and thoroughly tested before shipment.

The fire box and combustion chamber are completely surrounded by water. Front end smoke box is set within the boiler shell, which eliminates the objectionable projection on front above firing doors.

BASE — The base is of cast-iron in four sections and is fitted with shaking grates, bridge wall support, front ash and regulator doors, and rear cleanout door.

DOORS — The firing and front cleanout doors with baffles are of cast-iron mounted on cast-iron frames studded to boiler front head.

ACCESSIBILITY — All tubes are cleaned from front end and no openings are placed on side of boiler, unless specially required so that boiler can be set against side wall if space is restricted.

See Dimension Tables on pages 6 to 11.

FITTINGS — Each Class S Boiler is equipped with shaking grates, bridge wall fire brick, water column, water gauge, try cocks, steam gauge, safety valve, damper regulator, poker, rake, hoe and flue cleaner.

Class W and L Boilers are equipped with shaking grates, bridge wall fire brick, poker, rake, hoe and flue cleaner.

GUARANTEE — All INGLIS SUPREME Boilers are built to comply with interprovincial regulations and workmanship and performance guaranteed.

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, and have duly noted your instructions regarding the old ruin, and your invitation to submit a recommendation regarding the water supply system for the new building.

On the 5th inst. I wired you McQueen's tender of $1200.00 for the removal of the debris, the breaking off of the concrete walls below grade, and the filling in and levelling of the old basement. I received no reply to said wire. Since sending that quotation—which was the best I had received at that time—I have been able to get a much better figure from the contractors, through their local sup't, Mr. Ducharme. At first these people would not undertake this work at all, stating they had enough on their hands without it, but yesterday they agreed to tackle it on the understanding that they might do it at once, using surplus earth from the new excavation for filling in the old basement, and at a price of $500.00. After consultation with Mr. Gooderham, I decided to anticipate the Department's acceptance of this figure, and notified the contractors accordingly. This is much cheaper than we could possibly get this work done afterwards. I had previously accepted the only offer I could get for the twisted and tangled mass of ironwork, viz $50.00, from the Calgary Scrap Iron Co., and they now have their men at work removing the debris, and shipping it away. This reduces the prime cost of disposing of the old ruin to $450.00.

I enclose photos of the old ruin, from which you will see that there is an enormous amount of difficult work in removing the wreckage, breaking off the concrete walls, and filling in. The contractors now have a gang of hardy Frenchmen at work breaking off the walls, using Roman battering-rams, screw-jacks, sledges and levers. Earth from the new excavation is being dumped into the old basement as fast as the walls can be broken off and the debris removed.

Regarding the water supply system, I may say that in the
Original recommendations which were sent you last December, it was suggested that a tower and tank be installed similar in principle to those provided on the Blood Reserve, but as we are getting a building of fire-proof construction, it does not seem necessary to have so large a reservoir of water on hand. A 2500 gal tank previously authorized for Old Suns School is lying in the town here, and this tank should meet the ordinary requirements of the school. Unless otherwise instructed, I shall have it set up in the chamber marked "Pump Room" in the basement plan, and connected to the existing well. As this tank is of 6' diameter, and 15' in length, it is too long for the room in which it should be placed, so I propose extending the length of the pump room 4 or 5 ft., which will then leave the usual walking room in front, and accessibility all around it for inspection or repair. The extended wall will jut out from the main wall of that area, thus requiring 2 or 3 extra steel joists. The window will be moved out also, and will have a reinforced concrete beam over, and brickwork on either side and below, so that if ever the tank should require to be replaced, a suitable outside opening could be readily made by removing a small amount of brickwork instead of having to cut through a concrete wall.

With reference to the source of water supply, I should have preferred having the well come right in the pump room so that the entire service could have been under the one roof, but there is not time to have a new well drilled now without tying up the job, even if a well-drilling outfit were immediately available. I am therefore arranging to utilize the existing well in the old basement, and am having the contractor carry up a suitable concrete foundation from the former basement level to the level of the surrounding grade, on which we shall afterwards build a small well-house to house the pumping plant yet to be provided. You will readily understand that it is necessary to carry up this concrete foundation previous to the filling in of the old basement in order to avoid building on newly filled ground. The water will be conveyed from the pumping plant through an underground pipe to the pressure tank in the pump room of the new building.

I am gathering data on the most suitable type of motor-driven, deep-well pumping outfit, and shall make this service the subject of another letter. The contractors are installing a temporary pump for their own requirements.

The new excavation is well under way, temporary buildings are nearly completed, and excellent gravel is being hauled for the concrete. The weather is fine, but windy, and this morning we had a dust-blizzard of glorious proportions!

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

The contractors' superintendent, at present in charge of his firm's interests here, informs me that they have had very unsatisfactory results with gypsum partitions in a previous job. Re- Old Suns School, Gleichen, Alta.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Many thanks for your letter of the 26th instant. The instructions contained therein have been duly noted.

We shall change the stucco walls leading to Chapel from stucco to brick veneer and 4" tile. I have wired the Truscon Steel Co., of Winnipeg, notifying them of this change, so that the I Beams will be of sufficient strength to carry the slightly added load; also I asked them to send an extra I.Beam to span over the Servery where there is no carrying wall.

Both the Indian Agent and the Reverend Principal have requested that full size screens be placed over all windows, instead of the half-screens specified for most windows. The special reason for this request is that the locality is subject to bad hail storms, and that the windows would have been smashed several times in recent years, and particularly on one occasion, had it not been for the full-size screens used on the former building. The contractors quote an extra price of $250.00 for full size screens throughout. Will you please instruct me in this regard.

The Reverend Principal is very desirous that "accordeon" doors be installed instead of a solid partition separating the Boys' Class Rooms, the reason being that at times the entire space will be needed for concert and other purposes. The accordeon doors would slide back in two sections, from the central column, thus leaving the two class rooms as one large auditorium. The contractors' quotation for making the change is $527.00, and I should like your early decision with reference to this request.

Enclosed please find a list of "NOTES" pertaining to the new building, and which embody suggestions and requests emanating from the Principal after a careful scrutiny of the plans. Many of the items on the list are more or less trivial; and the cost of some of the things asked for can be met by savings in other items, as in Item 3. It would take too long to go over this list in detail, but you will understand them at a glance, and if there are any items unacceptable to you, will you kindly notify me to that effect.

The Reverend Principal asked me today if it would not be possible to provide a soft water cistern to receive the rain water from the roofs of the laundry and chapel. He states it is not only desirable to have some soft water for the laundry but that it is essential that water other than the well water be available for the heating boilers on account of the soda content in the well water causing the heating boilers to foam and blow off through the safety valves. Dear Mr. Smith:

The contractors have raised the question of fire escapes being omitted for in the fireproof construction decided upon. Their Superintendent, Mr. MacKinnon, seems to be under the impression that the fire escape shown and specified in the plans and specifications had reference to the original type of building intended, and not to the present fire-proof construction, and that they may now be omitted. I told Mr. MacKinnon that I had no authority for deviating from the original specifications in this regard, but would refer the matter to you. Please advise me in the matter promptly. Should the fire escape be omitted, we should place windows where the door exits are shown.

The contractors' St. Boniface office has written to me that telegrams and letters to Ottawa on the matter of authorizing the design of the heating boilers have not been answered, and as these boilers are yet to be manufactured, it is important to have an early decision, hence my letter on the subject to you this morning.

The work is making good progress, the concrete walls are completed, and yesterday a start was made on the brickwork. I enclose 3 or 5 snapshots taken about a week ago, and shall send others as the work progresses.

How Slaterock Is Made

The core or foundation of Slaterock is made from pure gypsum rock. The gypsum is mixed with a special mineralized fiber board, forming a tough, flexible blackboard surface. This thickness possesses all of the inherent properties of the natural slate.

Slaterock Blackboards are true and straight and will not warp, crack, or buckle. Changes in temperature or excessive moisture cannot affect them. They maintain their original shape and appearance. Because it is made from natural materials, Slaterock is impervious to moisture, and in the event of fire, it will not produce any smoke or fumes.

The Writing Surface

The writing surface of Slaterock is protected by a tough, flexible coating of a series of heavy layers of a unique composition which is applied to a uniform, hard, velvety writing surface. This makes Slaterock a dull blue-black chalkboard which is extremely smooth, wonderfully long-lasting and easy to write on. The writing surface is maintained by frequent tests of the writing quality and the overall appearance of the boards. Although Slaterock is treated with a protective coating, two coats of waterproofing are applied to the back of each board to prevent water from penetrating the board.

Lengths & Feet

Slaterock Blackboards are made in standard widths of 3', 5', 6', 8', 10', 12', 14', 16', 18', 20' (from 1' to 2'). Any desired length will be cut to order. As there is no contraction or expansion necessary in applying each board, no special tools are necessary in applying moulding to Slaterock surfaces. If necessary, Slaterock can be nailed all around. REPORT OF PROGRESS ON OLD SUNS SCHOOL.

Sir:

The general work of construction advanced at a very satisfactory rate of speed during Sept., Oct. and Novr., the weather being favorable for outside work. However, with the advent of December came snow and cold weather, and we are now in the grip of the worst storm yet experienced since the job started. For a full week the temperatures have been sub-zero, reaching 18 degrees below zero last night. To-day at 3:30 P.M., the thermometer is at 8 below, with a cutting north wind, and light snow falling.

The outside brickwork is temporarily halted by the cold weather. Most of the outside brick walls are completed, including the walls of chapel, laundry, both wings, and residence, but the last storey of the main building is not much more than started, and the chimneys are yet to be built. The bricklayers are now erecting the tile partitions in the basement, and to-morrow will start erecting the gypsum partitions in the residence. Storm sash have been placed in most of the window openings, and several coke-burning heaters have been set up, and a working temperature is thus obtainable for some of the inside mason work.

The heating boilers arrived a few days ago, and were got into place yesterday. The openings which had been left to admit the expected Spencer boilers proved inadequate for the boilers supplied, and considerable cutting of brickwork was inevitable to get them in. This was carefully done, and will be restored without detriment to the building. The heating boilers seem fully satisfactory, being much like the Birchfield boilers in use at the Lytton school, and are the product of the Vulcan Iron Works, of Winnipeg. The hot water storage tank and 10 H.P. high pressure boiler have also arrived, and it is proposed to utilize the latter boiler for temporary heat until the large heating boilers can be made ready.

The roofing contractor is also here, and to-day is laying the roofing paper over the residence, but I am advising him to await more moderate weather before starting on any
I am afraid of subsequent buckling of the roofing if laid in extremely cold weather.

The electrical sub-contractor is carrying along his work well, and keeping ahead of the trades which will follow.

The plumber is also well along with his roughing-in, and doing good work. I made a water test of his work as far as it was ready, and there was not a single leak.

The heating contractor's men were here some time in advance of the arrival of the boilers, and have the steam mains in place all through the basement, and are now making the connections to the boilers. The Trane heating specialties will be used on this job. I should have preferred the Dunham, but had no ground for refusing the Trane.

The concrete slabs have been run on all floors, and at present look satisfactory, but I shall examine them more closely when heat is available, and the frost driven out of the building. Should there be any faulty spots, I shall have them relaid in respect of same.

The roofs are all sheeted in, and ready for the tar and gravel, with the exception of the main building, as already mentioned.

The gypsum tile has been delivered in the building. I am in communication with the gypsum manufacturers, and have their detailed specifications for erection of same, which we shall endeavour to follow to the letter.

The rate of progress has inevitably slowed down in consequence of the extreme weather we are now experiencing, but we're hoping for the early arrival of a Chinook, and then we should be able to get back into high gear again.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir:

During my visit to the Old Sun School on November 1st last, my attention was directed to the need of a new switch for the electric motor in the sun-house of the stock barn, and also for the need of a heater to warm the motor in cold weather. I was informed that much difficulty was experienced in getting the motor heated effectively in the colder weather which had then set in, and also when on my way to the Carcross school in the bush and could not take the matter up with you myself, I suggested that this need be made known to the Indian Agent with a request that he should take any further action necessary.

As the motor has been installed on the wall of the sun-house at about 7' from the floor, it was suggested to me that it should be lowered to the floor, and also that a pump jack should be installed to take the place of the 12' pull rod which causes sufficient strain to put the motor out of commission prematurely. If you have not yet received any communication from Mr. Indian Agent Godberham in connection with these matters, I shall be deeply obliged if you will take them up with him at your earliest convenience and authorize him to effect any changes or improvements which he may consider necessary.

While visiting this school, I went carefully over the farm instructor's cottage, which your Department so kindly provided, and was very much pleased with the same. There were a few improvements such as storm windows for the basement, the placing of some of the windows in the sun-room on hinges, etc., which had not been provided, and I referred these to the Inspector of Construction on the new school for reference to you for further consideration.

The Farm Instructor, Mr. Bates, who is one of our most competent appointees for the position he holds, presented a strong request that the cottage be linked up with the water system of the main school building, and I undertook to refer the
request to you and ask for your favourable consideration of the same. Speaking for myself personally, I beg to state that I consider the request altogether reasonable. I do not know of any staff agent at our Society's Schools who is better entitled to the comfort which a bath would furnish than the farm instructor. In the cultivating and harvesting periods, he must frequently return from his work in a very labour-sodden condition and one can easily understand what a bath would mean to him at such a time. As matters stand at present, he is left without either a bath, or water for bathing purposes, or for the numerous household requirements unless it is carried in pails by himself or the bigger boy pupils from the main School building. I shall be very grateful, therefore, if you will reconsider this matter and grant the farm instructor's request to have a bath installed and the water laid on from the main school supply system.

I should like to make the same request with regard to the Farm Instructor's cottage at our Blood School. At the Blood School there is a room with a bath in it, but the building has never been linked up with the main School's water system. The expense involved at either school would be a very little, and I am of the opinion that if your Department supplied the materials, the school management would undertake the work of installation.

With the compliments of the season,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to advise you I have issued a 5th Certificate, for $19,440.00, to Wyndels Construction Co., general contractors for the above building, in payment of 90% of the value of labour and materials supplied by them on their contract to date.

I enclose a copy of the contractors' 5th Progress Estimate, which shows how the amount of the Certificate was arrived at.

As advised in my Report of the 11th instant, the work of construction had slowed down in consequence of severe wintry weather, and this condition has been continuous since. No outside brickwork worth mentioning has been done during the past fortnight, and there still remains to be done the carrying up of the top storey of the central portion of the main building, and the completion of the chimneys. A week or ten days of suitable weather should enable the outside brickwork to be completed.

The erection of the interior tile and gypsum partitions is completed, except for the unfinished portion of the main building. We followed the manufacturers' specifications closely, and it looks as if we have a satisfactory job. This work was done by the bricklayers when the inclement weather stopped outside work, and a limited amount of temporary heat was supplied by a number of coke-burning heaters.

The roofing sub-contractor made a start, and laid the roof over the Principal's residence, but I then stopped him as I was afraid of the roofing buckling afterwards when laid in very cold, stormy weather. He was a real Spartan for tackling it when he did. All the roofs are sheeted in readiness for the tar-and-gravel roofing, with the exception of the before-mentioned central portion.

The weather has recently moderated, and Chinook breezes have

Commenced to blow, so I trust better conditions for outside work will soon prevail. Deep snow covers the prairies.

Dear Mr. Orr:

During a recent visit to the building, Mr. G.H. Gooderham, Indian Agent, urged the desirability of installing the necessary wiring so that an electric range might be used in the Principal's residence. He mentioned that the Reserve is being brought under a much lower cost of electric current than before, and that, in his opinion, advantage should be taken of the lower rate in the instance mentioned, especially as the residence kitchen is rather small.

Under the new contract with the Calgary Power Co., the school will get a "commercial rate" of current, which will run from 5¢ to 10¢ per KWH, according to amount used, and Mr. Gooderham thinks the school will earn the minimum 5¢ rate during at least part of the year. For power purposes (laundry, pumping, etc) a power rate lower in cost than the commercial rate will obtain.

The contractors quote a price of $120.23 for running a feed from the distribution panel in the tank room connecting up with the power service, including all labor and materials, and making connection to the electric range in the Principal's kitchen. This would give the lower power rate, and would probably average out about 2¢ per KWH less than the commercial rate.

As an alternative, the contractors quote a price of $75.51 for running a feed from the main lighting panel in the Principal's office to the Principal's kitchen, making necessary connections, etc. This would come under the commercial rate.

The Rev. Principal asked me to mention that in the event of the Department sanctioning the proposal of the electric range, he will be willing to omit the usual range boiler in his kitchen, which he estimates will make a saving of about $40.00, the saving to be applied against the suggested extra wiring. Also, he states he would engage to pay the difference between the cost of the ordinary kitchen range and an electric range.

I promised the Indian Agent and the Rev. Principal that I would refer the matter to you for decision, and I would ask that you please wire a reply. In the event of this request being granted I want to have the wiring done ahead of the lathing and plastering.

Sir:

REPORT ON OLD SUNS SCHOOL, GLEICHEN.

Since my last Report the progress of construction has been greatly retarded by the extremely cold weather. Sub-zero temperatures, with snow and wind, have been almost continuous, reaching 45 degrees below zero. The result was we could not complete the brickwork of the central portion of the main building, or do any other outside work. The bricklayers have been idle for weeks. About three days ago the temperature commenced to moderate, and today at 2 P.M. the thermometer is at 26 degrees above zero, and our full crew of bricklayers are again at work. By the end of this week the top storey of the central part should be finished. The brickwork then to be completed will be the setting of all the coping stones, the completion of the front verandah and sun-parlour, the completion of the main chimney (about half up now), the kitchen chimney, the topping off of the ventilating flues, the cleaning off of the face brickwork, the building of the stair walls, and the laying of the enamel brick in the kitchen and scullery.

The heating contractor made an attempt to supply temporary heat in a good part of the building. He first tried the high pressure laundry boiler, but found he could not hold the water in the boiler, and lost a couple of days experimenting. He then had a temporary breeching made locally, and hooked up one of the large boilers, but again he could not hold the water, so had to have water hauled six miles from the river in 30 below zero weather, and fill the boiler with the river water instead of that from the well. Since then he has been able to deliver a fair amount of heat into the greater part of the building, and the various workmen were thus enabled to carry on. At present a number of radiators are connected on all but the top floor of the main building, and comfortable working temperatures prevail.

The gypsum partitions have been erected throughout except the top floor, and we appear to have a good job done. I received from the manufacturers detailed specifications and
explicit directions, which we followed to the letter. Of course it is too soon to tell how this material holds up, especially with regard to plaster cracks as complained of elsewhere. In the basement, as previously authorized, we built the partition walls of clay tile; and on the other floors we used clay tile for the bottom course because of its less porous surface for taking the concrete base.

The plumbing contractor has his roughing-in well advanced and in so far as I have yet been able to test his work it is well done, with tight joints, and neat workmanship. We are putting in the stand-pipe system just the same as called for in the specifications except I have asked for an extension of the feedline so that the protection will be available in both the top dormitories. We have connected the temporary pumping plant to the permanent pressure tank in the building, and find there is a small leak at one of the rivetted seams. If this leak does not take up I shall have a welder come and stop the leak by brazing the seam at the leaky spot.

Three painters are now at work glazing and painting the sash. They seem competent workmen, and are using good materials.

The plastering contractor has not yet arrived, and we saw in the paper an account of his being held up in Winnipeg just after he had drawn about $700.00 for the pay-roll of the plastering labour at the Brandon Indian school, and robbed of this large sum at the point of the gun. The plaster material has been delivered, and much of the building is now ready for lathing.

The roofer came at the commencement of the very cold weather, and made a start at laying the tar-and-gravel roofing, but after he had finished the roof of the Principal's residence I stopped him as I deemed it impossible to get good work done in such cold stormy weather. Word was wired to Winnipeg last night reporting milder weather, and asking that the roofing work be now proceeded with. This work must be done before it will be safe to start plastering.

Weather permitting, good progress should be made from now on. It is rather early to hazard an opinion as to when the job will be completed, but it looks at present that it will run into April.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

E. Gardner Smith

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Regarding the small open porch shown on the plans at the rear of the Principal's residence, the Rev. Mr. Gibney requests that this be closed in, and provided with a door and window. The reason he gives is that he fears his rear entry will receive the full force of the prevailing west wind, which often blows with great violence. Also it will receive the wind deflected from the adjoining blank wall of the school.

I recall that in the former building we had to build protection porches to keep the wind from striking the exposed entry doors—and this after two doors had been torn off their hinges and door checks, and their stiles split.

The contractors agree to make the desired change at a cost not exceeding $100.00, and as much under this figure as possible. Will you please instruct me whether or not this requested change may be made.

The Provincial Boiler Inspector, Mr. Dick, gave us a call two days ago while passing through the locality. I shall have him come again and make a more thorough inspection before accepting the heating plant. While here Mr. Dick stated that in his opinion it would be advantageous to place a flange in the line of steam main in the basement corridor, which he said would greatly facilitate making repairs in the event of future trouble, and might save having to send a 6" main to Calgary to be threaded if a Tee or elbow had to be replaced. The heating contractor's representative does not take kindly to the idea, and will expect to be paid for the additional time and material involved, which may amount to $20.00. I should like you to instruct me whether to carry out the Boiler Inspector's recommendation, or whether to omit the flange in question.

Dear Sir:

As mentioned in my telegram of yesterday, I called on the plastering contractors in Calgary mentioned by you with the exception of Mr. Alex. Cumberland, who was ill in bed at the time. I also had an interview with Mr. J.M. Wilson, Secretary of the Builders' Exchange, whose name and address you had also given me.

There was no question at any time regarding the wages being paid the plasterers, but the Calgary union demands that the plasterers employed be 50-50 Calgary men—that is to say for each outside plasterer there must be one Calgary plasterer too. Mr. Bowx, the plastering sub-contractor conceded this, and dismissed good plasterers who had paid their own fare to work here, and put on Calgary men in their place.

Regarding the rate of pay for labourers employed by the plastering contractors, I was advised by the persons to whom you referred me that in Calgary it is now the practice to pay all such men on the basis of "plasterers' helpers," viz. at $7½ per hour. I have therefore given a ruling to this effect, and the higher rate of pay will be made retroactive, in the case of all men who attend on plasterers, including wheelbarrow men, mixers, and hod carriers.

With reference to the complaints of Louis Ducharme, and the two brothers Laune, these men are making claims for carpenters, steel workers and hoisting engineers' wages for the time they were assisting artisans, or running a small gasoline engine hoist. The youth Ducharme is the son of the foreman, nineteen years of age, and worked in the offices as time-keeper, book-keeper, etc., pending the arrival of the contractors' accountant, Mr. Denick. He was then taken into the building at the same rate of pay as his own father had set on his services, and has since been working under the supervision of an experienced carpenter. This youth can not fairly claim carpenter's wages, as at the best valuation he is only an apprentice, and to concede such a claim would, in my opinion, be a gross injustice to the carpenter trade. He has a good knowledge of telegraphy, and I have seen his transit messages in the Gleichen station, but I am sorry that his talent in this respect did not hold him to that profession.

Now in Calgary I enquired as to the qualifications of a "hoisting engineer," and was told by several builders, and also by a hoisting engineer himself when at work at his hoist, that the term has reference to men qualified to operate a steam hoist, and will hold at least 3rd class papers. Any intelligent labourer, with but a few minutes' instruction, can operate such a hoist as has been in
operation at our job here, and every person among the builders I
consulted in Calgary agreed that only qualified engineers can fairly
claim a rating as "hoisting engineers".

Labourers are necessarily a movable quantity, and are frequently
called from place to place to assist where assistance is needed. On
country jobs particularly, labourers have no help to carry I beams,
columns, and other heavy materials, and assist in lifting them to
place, but such work does not, in my judgment, warrant a claim for
structural steel workers' rates, which is a trade in itself. Nor if
carpenters have two or three labourers calling for them to get a
roof closed in (as was the case here) during bad weather, this does
not, in my opinion, entitle a labourer to the wages of a qualified
carpenter because of this casual rough help. On this job the amount
of such work done by labourers is practically negligible, and in no
case has any but competent carpenters been employed at strictly
carpentry work, and they have been paid the fair wage rate of $1.00
per hour.

The claims of the plasterers' labourers, - or rather, claims
put forward on their behalf by the delegate from the Calgary Union—
have been satisfactorily adjusted, and everything is harmonious in this
trade. The claims of Louis Ducharme, Albert Louie and Gus Louie for
artizan's wages for part of their time, I have not endorsed. These
three men were hired as labourers at the start, they have done several
months' steady work, they were paid regularly as building labourers
at $3.00 per day, and rightly until pay-shoes demanded. Only when
they were laid off, when there was no longer any work for them, were
these claims brought forward.

I am sorry to say there has been growing friction between
the officers of the Syndicate Co. and Mr. Ducharme, the foreman. I
shall not go into the merits of the纠纷，but I am of the opinion
these fantastic claims for higher pay have their genesis in the bad
feeling which unhappily is all too evident. It looks to me as
inevitable that Mr. Ducharme be relieved of his position, and another
competent foreman put in his place. I am expecting a climax at any
time. Beyond seeing that good work is being done, I am trying to
maintain a neutral attitude.

Yours faithfully

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Mr. Harrison:

Your night letter of the 10th, sent from Port Arthur, reached me this morning. In the night letter are embodied complaints from several men purporting to say their wages are still owing them.

Each man whose name appears in said night letter has been paid up to his last hour of service, and in no case is there a single instance of any employee of the contractors being compelled to wait a single day for his pay when due. I inspected the pay-sheets this morning, and found therein the signatures of the complainants themselves, thus acknowledging the receipt of their wages.

The real crux of the situation is simply this: a number of the workmen who were hired and paid as labourers were laid off when there was no more work for them, and now they are coming forward with claims for the higher wages of skilled artisans in the various crafts. It is for back-pay, on this higher scale, that they are seeking. In the main, I consider these claims invalid, and not in keeping with recognized building practice.

When I have a chance to talk with you personally I shall be able to throw more light on the subject than I can do by letter. However, I may now say that it appears to me that these complaints and claims all have their genesis in the ill-will of a deposed foreman, and that he has implanted this germ of discontent in the minds of others, and I believe these claims for higher classification of work owe their inspiration to him.

I shall be glad to see you on your western trip.

Yours faithfully

(Sgd) E.Gardner-Smith.
Inspector of Construction.
