Re- Old Suns Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Orr:

With reference to a permanent water system for the above-mentioned school, you will recall that we are at present using the contractors' temporary engine and plant, and are pumping water from the old well on the site of the original building about 50' distant from the new school.

At the time of demolishing the old ruins, and filling in and grading, we carried up a foundation wall around the well, bringing same up to grade height, and thus having a secure foundation for a future well-house. The contractors placed a temporary wooden building on said foundation wall to give protection from the weather to the temporary pumping plant on the level of the former basement floor.

We shall soon require a permanent well-house, and I would respectfully suggest that a brick house be built, 10'x 10', for which the concrete foundation is in readiness. I could arrange with the contractors to erect this little building at proven cost, plus 10%, or get from them a straight tender. Will you kindly advise me as to the Department's wish. A suitable galvanized iron water line has already been carried underground from the well to the new school, and connected to the pressure tank there.

With regard to a permanent pumping plant for the new school, I have received three tenders from three different firms, each firm being given full data bearing on the requirements. The tenders received from two of the firms quote on equipment so manifestly unequal to the work that I am not considering them. The third tender is from L. Michael, of Gleichen, a copy of which I enclose. Mr. Michael has done a great deal of work for the Department, and his work stands up well. I enclose Cut and Specifications of the pumping plant Mr. Michael proposes to install, which I believe would prove very satisfactory over a long period of years. Mr. Michael has installed several pumping plants of this type, all of which are giving untroubled service.
The Crane pump quoted on has many excellent features among which may be mentioned the enclosed frame, self lubricating, silent chain drive, accessibility of parts, ease of withdrawing rods and cylinder, etc. It has a 5 HP Motor attached rigidly to top of frame. The 105OF model has slightly more lifting capacity than our well calls for, but on the other hand we shall pump against a maximum pressure of 70 lbs instead of the tank pressure of 40 lbs shown on the Table of capacities, which difference will thus be taken care of. (Our well is about 175' deep and Table shows the proposed plant equal to a well of 275')

Mr. Michael's quotation of $785.00 covers the entire work, including preparing suitable reinforced concrete base, removal of existing well equipment, installing the new equipment, extending the existing well casing, and leaving the new plant in perfect working order, and with 12 months' guarantee of satisfactory performance.

The proposed pumping plant will, of course, be provided with an automatic electric starter and cut-out, which will maintain a pressure ranging from say 35 to 70 lbs in the water supply.

I have no hesitation in recommending the acceptance of Mr. Michael's tender.

Awaiting your kind instructions regarding the well-house and permanent pumping plant,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 21st instant, claiming a balance of $1.35 to be due you on your October account for bread supplied to the Old Sun's Residential School, I beg to state that the account for that month was not rendered at $18.45 as stated in your letter, but at $17.10, which amount has been paid. In your November account for 220 loaves of bread, you include in addition to the amount of the bread supplied during that month an item marked "account rendered $18.45" which it is assumed represents the account for October. Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 16th instant with reference to various requirements for the outbuildings at Old Suns School, I beg to report as follows:

The electric motor at the stock barn should be wired from the power distribution panel in the new school instead of on a lighting service. This would give more power, and take a cheaper rate. To make this change would entail running two No. 8 conductors, change cross arms on existing poles, and extra guying, also necessary connections. The motor as at present installed in the pump house of the barn would not pass inspection, and should be wired in conduit, and provided with an externally operated switch. This service should also be grounded. To do this work, and make the changes indicated, would cost $105.00. To provide and install a suitable electric heater to keep the motor at a proper working temperature in cold weather would cost about $20.00, making a total cost of $125.00. I would not recommend a stove and chimney adjoining the barn because of fire hazard.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Quite apart from the information contained in my regular reports on the progress of the work here, I feel that I should like to tell you something of what has been going on beneath the surface.

Owing to the death of Mr. Wyndels shortly after the contract was let, this job was started under inauspicious circumstances. Mr. Ducharme, the foreman, promised a dying man that he would do all possible to make the undertaking a success, and to protect the interests of the Company employing him. He arrived on the scene in due course, and brought with him, or there followed soon after him, about a dozen French Canadian friends of his to work on the job. Things went quite well on the start, but it was not very long before friction developed. It seems a Mr. Tallieu, a Belgian compatriot of the late Mr. Wyndels—had come to the Company's assistance financially, and it was his money that kept the concern going. He arrived later on the ground, and noticing what he considered extravagance in the carrying out of the work, he asked Mr. Ducharme to curtail the seeming excessive pay-roll. Then the sparks commenced to fly. Mr. Ducharme flaunted a written agreement executed by the late Mr. Wyndels appointing him (Ducharme) foreman with full authority in all matters pertaining to the work, at a salary of $500.00 per month plus board and transportation, and to run one full year, and with no restraining conditions. He openly defied Mr. Tallieu, and encouraged his men to do the same. It so happened that the sub-contractors were mostly Belgian, and there seemed to be an undercurrent of hostility between the two races. During the past two months it has been my daily concern to avoid an open rupture, and to try to keep the peace between the rival crews until the job could be finished. The friction spread until I don't think there was a single man on the works but was more or less affected by the undercurrent of jealousy and ill-will, and the atmosphere was electric. In the meantime Mr. Tallieu had received from the Company's directors a legally executed document giving him full authority over the entire job, with authority to hire or discharge workmen. We then had two captains...
on the same ship, each at enmity with the other, and both with documentary authority. It was an impossible situation, and the climax had to come. Mr. Debuck, the accountant, became almost ill over the friction, and left on half a day's notice for Winnipeg. Mr. Tallieu, acting on his duly executed credentials, dismissed several of Mr. Ducharme's men despite the latter's denial of such right.

There was ample cause for these dismissals. In the first place the brickwork was just finished, which meant less labourers were needed; and in the second place a number of Ducharme's men, following his example, had left the camp and were boarding in town. As the Company had been to the expense of building and equipping the camp, and engaging a first class cook, an order had been given that only men boarding at the camp were to be employed. This order Ducharme defied. These discharged men, aided and abetted by Ducharme himself, then brought forward all sorts of claims for higher pay than they had been getting. It would take too long to explain this feature of the trouble in all its ramifications. I passed on them as fairly as I could, but my decisions were refused by the disgruntled ones, and led by Ducharme's 19 year-old-son, numerous telegrams (sent collect) were despatched to the Department of Labour, Ottawa, purporting to say that wages were being withheld. As time went on these discharged workmen plotted and schemed to extort more money from the Company, and the fantastic claims which evolved from their brains had by this time extended into higher mathematics. Then we had the unique spectacle of the foreman for the contractors, still drawing their money, and still under promise to do his best for the widow and orphans, taking a half-day off and going to Calgary with his dismissed followers, to start legal action against the Wyndels Company. Ducharme told me himself on his return that he had placed his own claims in a lawyer's hands, and that a suit would follow. I shall not take time to explain his strange grounds for suit.

In the meantime Mr. F.E.Harrison, Dominion Fair Wage Officer, was on his way West, and the day before his arrival Mrs. Wyndels, with a 6 mos. old nursing baby, arrived from Winnipeg to see if she could help in the crisis which had arisen. I met her at the station, and owing to the kindness of Mr. and Mrs. Hutchison, I was able to bring her to their home. The next day Mr. Harrison interviewed each claimant for higher wages in turn. He threw out about 75% of the men's claims, but made some allowances in their favour amounting to over $300.00 altogether. A day or two later, after consultation with the local lawyer, Mr. Tallieu and Mrs. Wyndels jointly signed a letter of dismissal, which was served on Mr. Ducharme, and they also dismissed Ducharme's two sons, and two others of that persuasion.
A law-suit was then inevitable between Ducharme and the Wyndels Company. This would mean the whole gang of mutineers would remain in the locality as principal or witnesses, and the publicity of it, and the consequent effect on our job, was something I was very desirous of avoiding. It was out of the question to try to bring Tallieu and Ducharme together; the enmity was too great. Acting as a disinterested intermediary, I finally succeeded in bringing Ducharme and Mrs. Wyndels together in friendly conference at Hutchison's home last Saturday night, and got them to agree on the sum of $358.00 in settlement of Ducharme's claims, and while they were both still in the mood, I slipped upstairs to my typewriter, and typed out a document covering all outstanding points, and they both signed it, and I witnessed it, at 11 P.M.

Next day Ducharme, his two sons, and three of the mutineers left by car for Winnipeg. Two mutineers, Maranda and Lauze, remain, and the former man, even after Mr. Harrison had allowed his claim in full, is still nursing some imaginary grievance, and told me he would continue sending night-letters to the Hon. Peter Henen ad infinitum, or until he gets his chimerical claims granted.

Mrs. Wyndels has appointed a local builder, Mr. Scott, to take over Ducharme's duties, and already the atmosphere at the job almost suggests the millennium after the previous conditions, and the utmost harmony now prevails.

The foregoing is merely a very brief outline of what has been going on; to tell it in full would fill a good sized volume. Never before was I ever involved in anything like so unpleasant a situation. Fortunately I was able to consult Mr. Gooderham, and his wise counsel and moral support were like the shadow of a rock in a weary land.

Needless to say, all the friction and disagreements have not helped to make the job profitable to the contractors. There has been no bad effects on the job itself, but the lack of harmonious cooperation, and active friction within the organization itself, certainly must have its reflex action on the balance sheet. I'm much afraid the job will not more than break even, and may do even worse than that. Probably the contract was taken at rather a close price. However, there has been no attempt to depart from the high quality of workmanship and materials called for, and the last job of the Wyndels Construction Company will, I feel sure, redound to their credit. For this reason, and also because all that Mrs. Wyndels possesses, including her late husband's life insurance, is invested in this undertaking, I would respectfully recommend that as far as possible any remaining work apart from the contract be awarded to the Wyndels Company. Now I must have pity on you and close this lengthy epistle. I am not often so verbose.

Sincerely yours

[Signature]

E. Gardner Smith

Most of the mutineers left by car this morning for their homes in Manitoba. By request, I saw them at the hotel last night, and listened to more of their whining. Sir:

Report on Old Suns School Construction.

Steady progress has been maintained in the erection of Old Suns Indian School here, and we are now within measurable distance of the completion of the contract.

The terrazza floors were completed this morning, and a very good job has been done by this contractor, Mr. Fabro, and his experienced assistants. The same crew were engaged to lay the cement floors in the various rooms where specified, and again I found their work very satisfactory.

The plastering of the building is well advanced, and should be fully completed next week. On the whole the plaster work is quite satisfactory, and so far remarkably free from cracks. My chief concern in connection with this branch of the construction was caused by the frequent high winds and dust blizzards which have been our almost everyday experience for weeks back. It seems that west of the school is a large area of bone-dry summer fallow, and clouds of this light powdery soil have been frequently blown by the prevailing west winds, thus enveloping the new building in a haze of dust, and which it seemed impossible entirely to keep out. Such a condition has not been conducive to the very best results in either painting or plastering, and occasionally gave rise to language scarcely in keeping with a missionary enterprise. However, not very much of the newly plastered walls suffered noticeably, and the plasterer has undertaken to remedy any smudged places before leaving the job.

The painting is proceeding at a fair rate of speed, and I have yet to meet a more worthy or more efficient exponent of this branch of art. And he has had his full share of tribulation too. The dust storms referred to have given him much extra work, and several times his paint has had to be scraped off and done again, and again. Through it all he remains unperturbed, indifferent to the buffettings of sand storms, and resolute in his determination to turn out first class workmanship. Truly this man is captain of his soul! He has four assistants who follow in his footsteps, and strive to emulate his high example of painstaking efficiency.

The plumber and steamfitter returned today to set up plumbing fixtures and radiators. This work will occupy at least another fortnight. These mechanics had left until the building was sufficiently advanced so that they could finish up all their work. In both these trades we are getting full satisfaction.
The sheetmetal and roofing is completed with the exception of the providing and setting up of the steel partitions for the small bathrooms off recreation rooms. These had been entirely overlooked by this contractor in figuring the job, and nothing sent. However, measurements have been sent him in Winnipeg, and these partitions will be installed as shown on the Plan.

Carpenters are hanging windows and doors, and setting up trim in the 2nd and 1st floors, these being now reasonably dry. We have received exceptionally good millwork from St. Boniface, and I'm very pleased with it.

The electricians are now drawing their wires through the conduits, and will soon be ready for hanging lighting fixtures.

From the foregoing brief resume you will see that the job is well advanced. I am still awaiting your valued instructions with reference to a well-house and permanent pumping plant, as dealt with fully in my letter of March 19th.

Another matter in which I am still awaiting the Department's decision is with regard to the cupboards, lockers, tables, pews, etc. Underdate of March 26th I wrote you, enclosing tenders I had received for this line of equipment, and asking for your kind instructions concerning these requirements. It will take some time at the mills, even after the order is placed, before this material can be delivered.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Re- Old Suns School, Blackfoot Reserve.

Sir:

With reference to my letter of March 19th regarding a well-house and permanent water service for the above mentioned job, I am not yet in receipt of the Department's instructions. As mentioned in previous correspondence, we carried up concrete foundations around the old well, the former building to carry a well-house 10'x 10'. The contractors installed a temporary pumping plant at the old well for their own use, and put a rough building over it as a protection against the weather.

We have already carried a gal. iron pipe line from the well to the new building, and connected it to the pressure tank in the room designated for that purpose. It now remains for the Department to erect the well-house and install a permanent pumping plant. In my letter of March 19th I gave my reasons for recommending the installation of a particularly sturdy and efficient Crane motor-driven (5 HP) pumping service.

I received the Department's authority to enclose the space under the two verandahs of the school for storage purposes. I am delaying this work pending the decision regarding the suggested brick well-house, for the reason that one small car of bricks will do both jobs.

In our new school building we have 86 casement windows. No adjusters are specified, and I'm certain if some means be not adopted for controlling these windows they will suffer serious damage, and will damage the plaster by swinging back against it. I have explored the market trying to find a suitable adjuster for windows swinging in, and adapted to our type of construction. The ordinary adjusters will not do. We might use a barrel bolt attached to the lower bar of the sash, but this would just allow the window to open a little; also there would be scratching of the stool. Ashdowns procured for me a sample "Rixson" adjuster which I have tried out and found fully satisfactory. It is attached to the top of the window frame and to the top rail of the casement,
and it works by tension, regulated by an easily operated set screw. In other words, a degree of stiffness is attained which prevents the sash from being blown about in the wind, and yet the sash can be readily pushed shut or drawn open as required. The adjuster when installed is up out of the way. Ashdowns quote a price of $1.25 each, and the adjusters would have to be imported, as I appear to have procured the only one in Alberta. If the Department considers the outlay too great to equip all the casements with adjusters, it occurred to me that perhaps it would answer well enough if we placed adjusters on the alternate casements where they come in pairs, and fasten the adjoining window shut. This would reduce the number to about 4 dozen. Or must we fall back on bolts? Will you please instruct me as soon as possible in this regard, so that these windows may be equipped against damage to themselves and to the plaster.

I duly received the Department's letter of the 24th ultimo giving additional names of firms from whom prices are desired for the cupboards, lockers, etc. Within a few days I hope to send the additional quotations for consideration.

The general work of construction is now well advanced, and the contract should be completed by the end of this month. I enclose a couple of snap-shots, but hope to have better photos of the building to send you soon.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sirs:

Our records show that the above quoted concern is undertaking a contract at the Old Sun School at Gleichen, which we understand is an institution under the administration of your Department.

Section 36-2 of The Workmen's Compensation Act of Alberta, provides as follows:

"Where any work within the scope of this Act is undertaken for any person, in this section referred to as the principal, by a contractor, it shall be the duty of the principal to see that any sum which the contractor or any sub-contractor is liable to contribute to the accident fund in respect of the work so undertaken is paid, and if any such principal fails to do so he shall be personally liable to pay it to the Board, and the Board shall have the like powers and be entitled to the like remedies for enforcing payment as it possesses or is entitled to in respect of an assessment."

In view of the above will you be good enough to authorize that no final settlement be made with the Wyndels Construction Co., Ltd., until there has been produced to you a Clearance Certificate from this office showing that all liabilities have been fully met.

Gentlemen:

With regard to the list of firms, and the amounts the Department is being asked to pay, in connection with the above contract, I wish to make the following explanations in those instances in which the balances shown in the letter to the Department differ from figures previously confirmed by you.

The amount of Mr. Fabro has been reduced by $101.70 as a result of a charge against him of $101.70 for electric current supplied by Old Suns School. A charge of $50.00 is levied against you also. I enclose the details of these charges, as submitted by the Rev. Principal. I understand Mr. Tailleau advised the Principal as to the apportionment of the electric bill as between you and Mr. Fabro.

R.J. McQueen notified me of a further charge of $5.50 for hauling bricks for the pump house, and as I have personal knowledge of this transaction I have added this small sum to his bill, thus making a total of $15.05.

Regarding the account of the Crown Lumber Co., I called at their Gleichen office the day before I left for Winnipeg, and the Manager being absent, his assistant gave me a memo purporting to show their balance to be $551.20. A few days ago the Manager, Mr. Watson, advised me that their account now stands at $753.00. I wired you for confirmation of this figure being correct, but in your letter of the 11th inst. you state you have no knowledge of any other figure than that of $551.20. Mr. Watson states that he wired me the day after I left for Winnipeg, in care of the Wyndels Co., stating his assistant had made a mistake, and that the then correct figure was about $100.00 higher. This telegram never reached me. I am adopting your suggestion of including this account at $551.20, and any additional sum due this Company will have to be dealt with later. Perhaps Mrs. Wyndels has not forwarded to you all the bills that have been sent to her.

The Beaver Soap & Chemicals, Ltd. state their balance at
$50.00, but in your list of June 17th this is shown at $780.13, the difference being accounted for by your deduction of freight $69.87, to which deduction I presume you are entitled.

The Macdonald Bros. Sheet Metal & Roofing Co., Ltd., sent me a Statement under date of June 20th, showing their balance as $2363.00. In going over this account with you in Winnipeg, a charge of $24.00 was added to this balance for a Tar Kettle; then a Contra Account of $534.35 was deducted, thus leaving the balance at $2852.65. This firm was not represented at our meeting in the Trustee Co.'s office, so on my return I wrote them asking for confirmation of the balance arrived at of $2852.65, and it was in answer to this letter that I was advised of the higher figure of $2363.00. I wrote again to this firm drawing attention to the divergence in figures, and asking them to confer with the Winnipeg Trustee Co. and get the difference straightened out. Under date of July 2nd I received the following message:- "Adjusting Wyndels Account with Winnipeg Trustee Co. (Stop) writing later." (Signed) The Macdonald Bros. Sheet Metal & Roofing Co., Ltd. I have heard nothing further from this firm, so in the meantime I am passing their balance at the figure agreed on when I was in Winnipeg viz at $2852.65, and any balance beyond that will have to be dealt with afterwards.

You mention that there is still some difference between you and the Manitoba Bridge Co. regarding the balance due them. I recall you were trying to obtain a small reduction in their account in consequence of losses sustained through waiting for steel. I am, therefore, passing this figure you gave me in Winnipeg viz, $1014.15, and any sum beyond this amount must remain unpaid for the present. If by any chance I am overstating this balance, you may have this figure amended by writing at once to The Deputy Superintendent General, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

The balance in favour of Brotherston Electric Co. Ltd., has been increased by $82.10, being the charge for the electrical connections to the motors of the laundry machines, thus bringing this firm's balance up to $1659.23. I wired Ottawa for a ruling as to whether this was a charge against the general contractor or against the Department, and was instructed to charge it to you. I enclose details of this charge of $82.10.

The Canada Seating Company have written me stating they have a claim against you for $225.04 for Blackboards supplied on your contract here. No mention was made to me of this account when I was conferring with you in Winnipeg. I wired asking if this balance is correct, and in your reply you referred to other matters, but passed this firm's claim in silence. Does silence give consent? I am having to defer taking any action to procure payment of this
account until confirmed by you.

The Sherwin-Williams Paint Co. regarding their unpaid account of $329.00, and although this balance was also included in my telegraphed inquiry, you made no reference to it in your reply. I enclose their letter to me, in which they appear uncertain as to whether their bill should be charged to your painting sub-contractors or to you.

May I urge that you give careful and immediate attention to all accounts not yet included, or fully disposed of, in the list forwarded to Ottawa? I felt that I should not take the responsibility of delaying the payments any longer, for some of these people appear to be pressed for money, and they have already waited a long time for settlement of their accounts.

I am sending you the various invoices, correspondence and other data which have come to me from your various creditors. The Department will obviously be unable to release the final balance that will be coming to you until all the outstanding accounts are disposed of, so please lose no time in sending me confirmation of any remaining balances, and I will do all I can to expedite the settlement.

You may now apply for cancellation of your Fire Insurance Policy on Old Suns School, and thus procure credit for the unexpired insurance. Perhaps you will have to send it to me for assignment.

You will note I am not differentiating between letters from the Wyndels Co., and from the Trustee Co.; but am treating them as from the same source.

Sir:

I beg to advise you that I am today forwarding to the Wyndels Construction Co., Ltd., Certificates No. 11 and 12 (final) in payment of their remaining balance in connection with the above mentioned contract. Bearing in mind your previous injunction against issuing Certificates in excess of $20,000.00, I have divided the sum due them of $24,528.63 into two Certificates of $14,528.63 and $10,000.00 respectively, which I trust was the right procedure.

I enclose a copy of the contractors' Progress Estimate No. 11, which shows how the amounts of the Certificates was arrived at.

I am also enclosing a copy of a letter addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General, and to be signed by the Wyndels Construction Co., in which the Department is being requested and authorized to disburse the monies at the credit of the contractors, including the deposit sent with the tender, in settlement of the various listed claims set forth in said letter. I regret that this list is not quite complete, but a very few supplementary items are all that remain, and I'm hopeful that these will soon be ready for submission, and then this ill-fated contract can be completely disposed of. In the meantime I think those creditors whose accounts are being forwarded to the Department should not be expected to wait much longer for their money.

I enclose, also, a copy of my letter of today to the Wyndels Co. regarding outstanding accounts and amended balances, which you may find informative.

Under separate cover I am sending you complete details of the additions, extras, and auxiliary work in connection with the Old Suns building. All the larger items, and most of the lesser ones, were authorized by the Department either by letter or telegram, and the list was gone over and explained when I had the pleasure of conferring personally with the officers of the Department when in the East a few weeks ago. If there should be any item in the list on which the Department desires further information, I shall be glad to make full explanation on being told of it.

The building is now completed, and the last of the contractors' workmen are leaving today. The Rev. Principal, Mr. Gibney, and family are already in residence in the new quarters provided, and I have asked Mr. Gibney to be responsible for the care of the building after tomorrow. The local contractor, Mr. W.T. Scott has also finished installing the new millwork, etc., but a few days' painting in connection with this work remains to be done.
Despite the handicaps under which this contract has been carried out, --the death of the president and manager of the contracting firm, the labour troubles, the disloyalty of the foreman and his satellites-- the Department is receiving a high class building in every respect, and although a certain loss was inevitable almost from the start, there was no attempt to evade the high requirements of the Specifications at any time. Unfortunately a heavy loss has resulted, and Mrs. Wyndels will be left almost, if not quite, destitute, even her late husband's life insurance, which had been pledged as collateral, being wiped out. This is doubly regrettable as she is left with 6 or 7 young children. The job was taken at too low a price, and it proved impossible to keep their costs down to their estimates. The Department is getting this fine building at about $10,000.00 below cost, and as this firm were not strong financially, the result is bankruptcy for them, I'm afraid. However, such are the fortunes of contracting, and stern fate is no respecter of widows and orphans.

The additional pressure tank salvaged from the former Old Sung School has just been joined to the existing one at the pump house of the Hospital, which doubles the water reservoir, and is already much appreciated. A Voucher for this work will be issued soon. This work was authorized by Mr. Orr, and is being performed by Mr. Michael of Gleichen.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

E. Gardner-Smith
Inspector of Construction.

P.S. In addition to the loss sustained by the general contractor, the sub-contractors lost money in most cases too. The plasterer went broke, and left many unpaid bills which Wyndels Co. had to shoulder,—but we got an excellent plastering job. The plumbing & heating contractor (Daoust) reports a loss of over $1200.00. Other sub-contractors about broke even, or made bare wages.

OTTAWA, Ont.

Sir:

Yesterday I had a call from Mr. French, of the Water Branch of the Department of the Interior, who had just come down from St. Paul. He reports the new well as yielding over 600 gals. per hour on a baling test. The water seemed of good quality except that a good deal of fine sand came with it, which may lessen as more water is used.

In discussing the matter of pumping plant, water storage, etc., we thought it would be best to wait until the contractors have drawn a lot of water from this well for their construction work before deciding on the most suitable equipment. We shall then have a better idea whether we shall have sand to contend with or not. The contractors will install their own temporary pumping service.

Mr. French said the excavating had commenced the day before he left, and should be completed within the next few days. I propose leaving for St. Paul by to-morrow evening's train from Gleichen so as to be present when the actual construction work starts. The contractors have shipped in a rock crusher, and propose crushing their own stone. A large pile of rocks and small boulders have been hauled to the site by local people, and these stones are clean and hard, and of good texture, and if broken up to correct sizes, excellent concrete should result. I approved a sample of sand, which I had subjected to a careful test.

While here Mr. French inspected the pumping plant at both Old Suns School and the Indian Hospital, and thought something somewhat similar would be about right for the Blue Quills School. I expect to return to Gleichen for a day or two within a couple of weeks' time in connection with a little work not yet quite finished.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

E. Gardner Smith
Inspector of Construction.

Sir:

The Winnipeg Trustee Company of Canada, who are looking after the affairs of the Wyndels Estate, write me as follows:

"In regard to the Workmen's Compensation Board of Alberta, we think the estimated pay-roll for $5000.00 is about right, and we are satisfied that Mrs. Wyndels has no objection to the government holding the necessary amount to pay for it, and thank you for your kindness in the matter.

"We have not heard from Ottawa at all since we sent them the different papers, and one of the parties here in Winnipeg phoned us yesterday. We wish Ottawa would send them their cheques, as really it is a hardship on some of those parties.

"We will have another small sum to pay to the Crown Lumber Co as we have final explanation of their account.

"We will as soon as we can, send you the list of two or three other small accounts to be paid in order to entirely settle this matter.

"We believe that likely the best thing will be that when everything is settled, Ottawa sends in our care a cheque to the Wyndels Construction Company, and we will see they all agree together before the cheque is used.

"As far as we can figure, there should be about $8000.00 left of the original deposit."

I realize it is very probable that by this time cheques will have been sent by the Department to the various creditors whose accounts have been accepted by the Wyndels Co. and sent to you for direct payment. As there are still two or three other small accounts in process of adjustment, I make the suggestion to send whatever portion is left of the original deposit in care of the Winnipeg Trustee Co. This seems a very reliable concern, and I have every confidence that they will see that all accounts are paid.

With regard to the claim of the Workmen's Compensation Board of Alberta, I called at the Board's office when last in
Edmonton, and the Board agreed to accept the estimated pay-roll of $5000.00 for 1930, and were to advise you of the amount due from the Lyndel's Co. on that basis, with the request that you make payment to the Board direct of the prescribed assessment.

I think this item of Workmen's Compensation is the only account in addition to the list sent you by the Winnipeg Trustee Co. that calls for direct payment from Ottawa. Anything then remaining will be very small, and can be dealt with by Winnipeg Trustee Co., as suggested in their letter.

I'm sorry that the Department is being troubled in this way, but as the contractors are apparently bankrupt in consequence of losing heavily on the Old Suns contract, the procedure being followed seemed the only way of protecting the various creditors.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Re- Old Suns School, Gleichen, Alta.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith the account of Mr. Michael, of Gleichen, for $292.76, being the cost of labour and materials for applying additional tar and gravel to the roofs of the above mentioned school.

This bill may come somewhat as a surprise to the Department, and calls for a special explanation.

Owing to winds of almost cyclonic violence, and which blew many crops of the district right out of the ground, some damage was caused to part of the tar & gravel roofing over the south wing of the main building. The suction of the wind "drew" the roofing into slight corrugations, and which would ultimately cause leaks if not remedied. Donald Bros. of Winnipeg, the roofing subcontractors, assumed responsibility for the repairing of the damaged portion, and this expense is being charged to them, as you will note from the enclosed letter to that firm. While Mr. Michael and his men were on the job with the necessary equipment, I took it on myself to authorize the applying of additional screened gravel, and to give the entire roof of the main building and residence a further dressing of tar. This has developed into a more extensive job than expected, but in my absence Mr. Michael conferred with Mr. Gooderham, and they deemed it best to make a thorough job of it while in the business, and altogether 18 bbls of pitch, and much more screened gravel, has been applied. When I tell you that in a neighboring municipality a new school had its tar & gravel roof blown entirely off the building, you will have some idea of what these roofs have to stand in the windy belt of Alberta.

This additional work on the school roofs is no reflection on the roofing contractor, for their work was done in full conformity with the specifications.

When in Gleichen last week I made a careful inspection of the extra work done on the roofs, and I can assure the Department that the expense incurred will prove an excellent insurance against the extreme vagaries of the weather for many years to come. These roofs are now models of solidity and weather resistance.
2.

Dear Sir:

Re: Wyndela Construction Co., Ltd.

Within recent date we requested the Workmen's Compensation Board at Winnipeg to assist us in clearing up our account against the above mentioned concern who undertook a contract at Gleichen for the Department of Indian Affairs and which operations came within scope of The Workmen's Compensation Act of this province.

The Wyndela account was established in the usual way and an assessment levied upon them which was never paid. Had any of their workmen during the process of the contract had the misfortune to sustain any injury this Board would most certainly have been left to pay notwithstanding the employers delinquency.

It is now found that the Winnipeg Trustee Company of Canada is custodian of the affairs of the Wyndela Construction Co., Ltd., and after communicating with the Department of Indian Affairs in an endeavor to get our account settled we are finally referred to yourselves as per letter from said Department dated September 17th, 1930, of which a complete copy is attached hereto.

We are now advised by The Workmen's Compensation Board of Manitoba that if you can be shown proof of indebtedness that payment of the same would be made by yourselves.

The original assessments were sent out to The Wyndela Construction Co., Ltd., by registered mail and I now attach hereto certified copies of such assessment notices and I also attach carbon copy of the original medical aid memorandum, but of course it is impossible for us to say what has become of the originals which we consigned to the addresses shown on the documents in question. equally positive that the charges in question are

Dear Mr Orr,

At the time of your visit to Old Sun School, you asked me about our heating system, but as I had not had opportunity to test it out under proper conditions I said that I could not tell you anything about it. You then asked me to let you know how things were later on. I have now had opportunity to give it a good test and report as follows:

The main part of the building is in good working order, and now the equalizer is in, the boilers are O.K.. The only part of the building that causes difficulty is the residence (Principal's) and here it is almost impossible to get heat. When the boilers are running full blast, so that it is unbearably hot in the main building, we barely get the tops of our radiators hot in the residence. We freeze in the top bedrooms in mild weather.

During our testing time I thought that I would try to get a fair idea of what temperatures we could obtain, so I used a maximum and minimum thermometer in my bedrooms. I found that the temperature never rose beyond 50 degrees, and usually stood at about 40. This was with both boilers going full and a calm day. That end is the North end, although I have not bothered to test it, I am certain that when slight breeze is blowing, the temperature would not be far off freezing point.

When Mr Walker was down, I spoke to him about it, and he tested the radiators, finding them alright. He said that the only way to get heat to the residence was to carry a separate line direct from the boiler to that end of the building. In case you thought of doing that, he left a plug in the main line just above the equalizer.

With kindest regards, and many thanks for the interest you have taken in fitting the school out.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
John W. House, Principal.

Dear Sirs,-

Re Indian School built at
Gleichen, Alberta, this year.

The Wyndels Construction Company
were the general contractors on the work.
Mr. L. Boux was the plastering contractor.
We supplied the plaster to Mr. Boux for this
work, prepaying the freight on it to Gleichen.

Shortly after the work commenced
Mr. Wyndels died, causing considerable confus-
ion as to what procedure was necessary to
protect our interests on the work. We assumed
that since it was a Government contract those
supplying materials would be protected, particu-
larly as we were given to understand it was
impossible to apply a lien on a building erected
under the Indian Department.

Our bill against Mr. Boux amounts
to $1837.50, of which $576.10 was for prepaid
freight on the material from Winnipeg to Gleichen.
We have been unable to get any payment whatever
from Mr. Boux. He advises us that he is insolvent.
We have been unable to obtain any payment from the
Wyndels Construction Company Estate being handled
by the National Trust Company, who advise us that
Boux is already overpaid on the work.

We are writing to ascertain what
stand your department is taking in connection
with materials supplied on this work for which
no payment has been received.

Yours very truly,

W.E.A.

Dear Mr. Gurney Orr:

Yesterday I made a test on the heating plant at the Old Sun School, Gleichen, and I was very pleased indeed with the manner in which the Residence heats up. Without any pressure showing on the gauge, every Rad in this part of the building was hot, and the temperature was 72°.

The House seems to be very pleased indeed, and I asked him to write you and explain just how he felt about the heating of his residence.

If you will remember, the dairy part of the building and the room where the storage tank was situated, the Rads in this part of the building would not heat up, and I was afraid that if we got a cold snap, that much damage would be caused to this tank, so I had the steam-fitter make some changes, with the result that the Rads now heat up very quickly, and there is absolutely no danger from freezing now.

Since we made the changes to the heater in the Residence part of the building, the whole school seems to heat better, and on testing out, I found that every Rad in the building, with the exception of the basement Rads which are on the wall, would heat up with no pressure showing on the gauge. The boiler and Rads of course would heat up when slight pressure was put on the boiler.
I also paid a visit to the Hospital Job. The new boiler is hooked up and everything appears to be heating nicely, but I will give it a thorough check over when the installation is finished.

By installing the steel boiler on this job, the heat was never cut off, as they had steam on the new boiler before they cut off the old one.

Yours very truly,

A. Walker

Dear Sir:

Re attached Voucher #483 in favour of F.J. Lepper & Company, I have to report that the heating system at the Old Sun School is now working splendidly with uniform heat throughout the building and with a considerable saving in fuel.

On completion of the line to the residence it was noted that the subsidiary system for the laundry, dairy and pressure tank room was giving practically no heat. If it had been severely cold weather this would have been disastrous. Before working on this system, I had Mr. Lepper come from Calgary and explain, as best he could, what would be necessary to get heat into these rooms. As the electric pump was then installed for the long distance work to the residence, the work in putting the subsidiary system into good order was not great and was done before Mr. Lepper took his mechanics off the job.

Dear Mr. Gooderham:

Since returning to Winnipeg I have gone carefully into the matter of the best kind of weatherstrip to make the new Old Sun School dust-proof, and strongly recommend the "Peace" weatherstrip, samples of which I am forwarding to you by rapid mail today. Enclosed herewith you will find the original of a letter from the Manager of the Peace Weatherstrip Company and a copy of the same, giving the price per foot of the different kinds of weatherstrip for windows, French windows and doors. The "Peace" weatherstrip double brass grooves is dearer than the other kinds but it is undoubtedly the best for the windows. You will note that there is a weatherstrip meeting rail to close up the space where the upper and lower sashes meet. This seems to me to be very important. I may state for your information that I have consulted Mr. Clayton of the Clayton Co Ltd., who built our Blood School, also Mr. James O'Keefe built our Sioux Lookout school, and Mr. James T. H. Matteson, chief architect of the Dominion Govt. in this city, and all three men spoke in the highest terms of the "Peace" weatherstrip and of Mr. H.J. Dennis the manager of this company. I have therefore the fullest confidence in recommending that the "Peace" weatherstrip be utilized in making the Old Sun School dust-proof. There are other kinds of weather-strip but they will not be so practical. I shall be glad to be guided in the course of the decision which you and your Department may reach in this important matter.

I have not forgotten the question of the terrazzo floors but so far have been unable to locate the firm that installed them. I asked Mr. Inspector Bunn to help me in this matter but he had no information on record.

Best wishes,

Yours very truly,

Signed: T.B. Westgate.
March 3, 1931.

Attention Mr. R.C. Orr,

Re: Old Sun School windows & doors

Dear Sir:

I attach hereto copies of letters from Dr. Westgate and the Manager of the Peace Weatherstrip Company of Winnipeg. Considerable time and thought has been given to find a remedy for the loose and shrunk condition of the windows and doors. Various schemes were suggested by local contractors but nothing appeared to be entirely satisfactory.

After the school opening Dr. Westgate kindly offered to get data in Winnipeg and his letter is the result. Where some windows have shrunk, a strip of wood will be necessary as well as the weather strip, I believe. This is mentioned because the "Peace" factor may not apply to this. It was ascertained in February that it is almost impossible to get windows or wooden construction which will not shrink and become loose in this dry climate. This is certainly evident at Old Sun school as most particle rail windows are loose in every direction and basement windows have shrunk and even warped to the extent that they are far from weather proof.

There is a heavy dust storm today and I believe the standard grommet "Peace" strip is the only thing that will keep most of the dust out of the building. On such a day the school is a terrible mess. Something must be done and it is presumed that you are familiar with this weather strip. The Principal advises me that the Company has offered measurements of all windows and doors and have been given the information. Awaiting your instructions.

Dear Sir:

As the Old Sun School is to be placed on the per capita grant basis from April last, next (see your letter Feb. 12, #104-1-2) I requested the Principal to furnish me with a list of buildings, equipment, etc., required to complete the school plant before that date. In his reply, just received this morning, he mentions the following items:

BUILDINGS:
(1) Poultry house with a capacity of 200 birds. Estimated cost $400.00. The Principal states that the present building has been condemned as useless by a Government Inspector.

(2) Piggery. Estimated cost $400.00. The building now used for this purpose is less suitable than the one used for the poultry.

EQUIPMENT:
(1) One waggon complete with high boxes and broad tires. The Principal states that with one waggon it is impossible to haul the school's supply of coal and the Railway Co. charges demurrage after the car has been on the siding for two days.

(2) Electric ironer, 54". The Principal stated that this method of ironing would be cheaper to operate than the coal stove which is in use at present. Cost?
(3) An electric scrubber and polisher for the terrazzo floor. Estimated cost about $600.00.

For some reason or other which the school management have not been able to ascertain, very fine sand-like dust keeps coming out of the terrazzo, and the Matron finds it impossible to keep the building clean. I have been unable to find out the name of the firm who installed the terrazzo, and beg to suggest that you direct their attention to this defect in their workmanship.

(4) All the doors and windows should be supplied with weatherstrip on account of the dust storms which are frequent in that part of the country. In a letter dated March 5, the Principal wrote, in part, as follows:

"We have just had two solid days of dust and everything looks like it. On Tuesday it was like a London fog and we had to burn lights all day. The inside of the school is like a ploughed field. Russian thistles were piled up around the girls' entrance, but to such a height that the Head Matron could not see out of her window, and they are hanging on everything outside."

I took this matter up with Mr. Indian Agent Gooderham when I visited this school at the time of the official opening Feb. 17th., and have since written to him very fully recommending strongly that the "Lease patent metal weatherstrip" be supplied, before taking this recommendation I consulted contractors who have already built schools for your Department, also Mr. Inspector Bunn, and Resident Architect H. E. Macdonald, Chief Architect's Branch, Public Works of the Dominion Government in this city, and all were of the opinion that no better weatherstrip is on the market. The Manager, Mr. H. J. Dennis, 285 Stradbrookes Avenue, Winnipeg, submitted samples and estimates, and these were forwarded to Mr. Indian Agent Gooderham. As the health of the staff and pupils and the efficient management of the school will be influenced by this improvement, I beg to request that it receive your prompt and favourable consideration."
(5) Provision for watering stock on the pasture land.

There are about 800 acres of pasture land without any water supply whatever except in the well which was put down in the basement of the old mission house about half a mile away from the school. The Principal suggests that a windmill and trough might be installed at this well for watering purposes, and I commend this suggestion on your sympathetic consideration. I would also commend to your sympathetic consideration the question of having the land attached to the school connected up with the irrigation system which I was informed is to be brought to the town of Clecheren. The Principal was of the opinion that this connection could be made without an exorbitant expenditure, and I beg to recommend that you ask Mr. Indian Agent Gooderham to take up the matter and furnish you with further detailed information.

The question of meeting the cost of light and power at this school is giving our Commission a great deal of anxiety at present. At the time of my visit to the school last February I was informed that an expert from the Calgary Power Company was about to visit the school and I awaited a report on his finding before taking the matter up with you. In a letter, dated March 16th, the Principal states that this expert visited the school but could not see much possibility of a reduction in the cost of the power consumed, as the equipment installed required the full capacity of power to operate it. He states that the cost of power alone will be between $50.00 and $60.00 per month the year around.

With regard to the cost of light, he states that the only possible way of effecting a reduction would be by substituting bulbs of smaller wattage for those already in use. In a number of the rooms this could not be done without injury to the eyesight of the staff and pupils, but that smaller bulbs might be used in the dormitories. The chief consumption of light, the Principal states, is in the basement and in the corridors which are so dark that some of the lights must be kept going all day. The bills for December (only half the month full operation) amounted to $100.80; for January $116.30; for February $102.70 (figures quoted from the Principal's letter). He estimates that the cost of light and power for the year will not be less than $1,750.00 with an additional sum of $50.00 for new bulbs, fuses, etc.
In the light of these figures you will understand the anxiety of our Commission as to how so heavy an expenditure is to be met with the present pupilage, and at the present rate of the per capita grant of only $165.00 a year.

I took this matter up with Mr. Indian Agent Gooderham at the time of my visit, and informed him that our Commission would be obliged to ask for some help in meeting this heavy expenditure.

I shall be obliged, therefore, if you will give this matter careful consideration and arrange to provide the additional financial help required in any way within your power.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the list of buildings, equipment, etc., furnished you by the Principal of the Old Sun Indian Residential School.

Relative to the erection of a poultry house and piggery, I have to say that the Department has no funds at present to provide the cost of these buildings. We are not prepared to supply an electric ironer, and an electric scrubber and floor polisher are not supplied.

It is the practice to ask the school management to pay for electricity from per capita earnings or other receipts. Our funds for the next fiscal year will be extremely limited, and I regret that only the more urgent buildings, equipment, etc., can be favourably considered.

You will be written in separate communications regarding the farm wagon; the supplying of weatherstrip; the installing of a windmill and trough for watering purposes and the question of having the school land connected up with the irrigation system in the town of Gleichen.

RE: Old Sun School windows and doors.

Dear Sir:

I attach hereto copies of letters from Dr. Westgate and the Manager of the Pease Weatherstrip Company of Timmins. Considerable time and thought has been given to find a remedy for the loose and shrunk condition of the windows and doors. Various schemes were suggested by local contractors but nothing appeared to be entirely satisfactory.

After the school opening, Dr. Westgate kindly offered to get data in Canada and his letter is the result. Where windows have shrunk, a strip of wood will be necessary as well as the leather strip, I believe. This is mentioned because the "Pease" people have not realized this. It was ascertained in Calgary that it is almost impossible to get windows of wooden construction which will not shrink and become loose in this dry climate. This is certainly evident at Old Sun School as most existing rail windows are loose in every direction and adjacent windows have shrunked and even warped to the extent that they are far from weather proof.

There is a heavy dust storm today and I believe the standard groove "Pease" strip is the only thing that will keep most of the dust out of the building. On such a day the school is a terrible mess. Something must be done and it is presumed that you are familiar with this weatherstrip. The Principal advises me that the Company asked for measurements of all windows and doors and have been given the information.

Awaiting your instructions.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Gooderham:

Since returning to Winnipeg I have gone carefully into the matter of the best kind of weatherstrip to make the new Old Sun School dust-proof, and strongly recommend the "Peace" weatherstrip, samples of which I am forwarding to you by parcel post today. Enclosed herewith you will find the original of a letter from the manager of the Peace Weatherstrip Company and a copy of the same, giving the prices per foot of the different kinds of weatherstrip for windows, French windows and doors. The "Peace" weatherstrip costs brass 40cvs. is cheaper than the other lines, but it is undoubtedly the best for the windows. You will note that there is a weatherstrip sealing rail to close up the space where the upper and lower sashes meet. This seems to me to be very important. I may state for your information that I have consulted Mr. Taylor of the Harbour Co. Ltd., who built our block school, and Mr. Matthews, Chief Architect of the Dominion Govt. In this City and all the men stood in the highest terms of the "Peace" weatherstrip and of Mr. Smith, the manager of this Company. I have, therefore, the fullest confidence in recommending that the "Peace" weatherstrip be utilized in making the Old Sun School dust-proof. There are other lines of weatherstrip but they will not be so successful. I shall be glad to be advised in the course of the decision which you and your Department may reach in this important matter.

I have not forgotten the question of the terrazo floors but so far have been unable to locate the firm that installs them. I asked Inspector Dunn to help me in this matter but he had no information or record.

OLD SUN'S C. OF E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

As this school has just recently been opened, there is very little that I can report upon. At the time of my visit there were 72 children in residence. There is practically an entirely new staff at this institution. The Rev. J. W. House, is in charge as Principal, and the staff consists of 10 - 7 women and 3 men, including the Principal. From my observations of Mr. House and the staff, I would say that there is quite an improvement here. The Principal is energetic and active, and appears to have some force behind him.

Naturally, a man of this type would demand a better staff, and I would say, from the Department's point of view, that this part, which is an important one, is quite satisfactory.

There is a tremendous lot of work to be done around the premises in the way of cleaning up, re-arranging the grounds, and getting them in shape, and a good start has certainly been made.

The farming operations are very discouraging as the top soil on their farm land, consisting of approximately 300 acres, had practically all blown away. This land is comparatively light, and it is absolutely useless to try to farm it under present conditions. One hundred acres have been sown to coarse grain, and 40 acres to grass. It is the intention of the Agent and Principal to seed all this land to grass and coarse grain. Feed is going to be a valuable asset in this part of the country, and hay would be of just as much value to the school as grain. The Agent had already suggested to the Principal that he break up 100 acres of prairie land, which is available.
available in the valley towards the river from the school. I think this would be a good idea as no doubt there is more moisture there and less wind. This land could be used for the purpose of sowing wheat, oats, etc. The Principal, however, did not know whether he would have time to break up this land this summer or not. As an old irrigation ditch runs around this land, if surplus water comes down through the C.P.R. spillway, they might be able to irrigate this part at very little cost. The matter is being looked into by the Agent.

The school has a very good herd of milk cows, 12 in number, mostly holsteins, 10 of which were milking, so the children are getting an ample supply of milk. They have approximately 25 head of cattle altogether, and 11 good horses. The Principal brought to my attention the fact that he needs a holstein bull as the one he has should be destroyed as he has become quite vicious. It occurred to me that Dr. Murray had a 4 yr. old bull which we purchased from the C.P.R. Farm at Strathmore, and for which he has no further use. I advised Mr. House to see this bull, and told him that the Department might be willing to turn it over to him. If he decides that this animal would be suitable, a request will no doubt be made by the Agent.

Pigs and chickens are also kept at the school. The boys do the milking in the winter, and the girls in the summer.

The school building, as you are aware, is new; it was only opened in February of this year. They are experiencing a great deal of difficulty in connection with the windows. They have shrunk until there is a space of about
OLD SUN C. OF E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

about one-eighth of an inch between the outside of the window and the casing. The dust that has been blowing in is terrible; although they still had all the storm windows on, there was dust all through the building. It was being cleaned up all the time, but there was so much of it coming in that it was impossible to keep it clean. The Agent has taken up with the Department the matter of tightening the windows, but nothing definite had been decided upon. I wish to point out that something should be done to remedy this condition as, when winter comes, if the windows are not tightened up in some way, there will be sufficient cold air coming in to make the school impossible to live in.

I have the honour to be,

Re- Windows at Old Suns School, Gleichen, Alta.

Sir:

No. 104-1-5.

In reply to your letter of May 7th regarding reported looseness of windows in the above school, I may say that on the 5th instant I visited this school, as instructed, and made a careful inspection. I was accompanied by the Indian Agent, Mr. Gooderham, and by the Rev. Principal, Mr. House.

There has been very little, if any, more than normal shrinkage in these windows. It is impossible to fit windows so tightly under winter-time construction that when they become exposed to the extreme heat and dryness of southern Alberta's summer climate a certain looseness will not develop. At the time these windows were fitted, the painters complained that it was almost impossible to raise them. However, regardless of the cause, it must be admitted that a considerable shrinkage has taken place, with very trying consequences to the inmates of the building, as I shall try to point out.

It may be recalled that in my regular reports sent to the Department during the construction of this school, I made references to the frequent and almost overpowering dust storms driven over the school site by the strong prevailing west winds. So bad was this condition at times that it seriously interfered with the progress of the work, and the workmen had to be supplied with fur-lined aviator's goggles to enable them to carry on. As the building approached completion it was found that even then, with absolutely tight windows, the fine smoke-like dust penetrated to some extent, to the great chagrin of the plasterers and painters.

Since the completion and occupancy of the school the conditions have grown worse. The windows have inevitably become somewhat looser, and raging west winds have forced dust into the building to an almost unbelievable extent. To appreciate fully the conditions it may be well to point out that Old Suns School finds itself in the very path of a dust blizzard every time the prevailing west wind blows, during dry weather; and as the late seasons have been unusually dry, with abnormally frequent and high winds, this condition has been the rule rather than the exception. To make matters still worse, there is a large field of summer fallow S.W. of the school where it has been the intention to get a catch of hay, but owing to
successive dry seasons this has been found impossible, and the necessary working of the land to keep down weeds, has had the result of providing a never failing dust reservoir for the winds to draw upon. Apart from this, the lightness of the soil in the locality is such that this particular location will always be subject to more than the usual amount of dust. Even the added protection of storm-windows is not sufficient to prevent dust penetration, and additional special protection seems called for.

Previous to visiting the school I took some pains to investigate what was being done elsewhere to exclude dust. I found that in the Calgary schools it had been found necessary to provide the windows with additional protection, and that the school architect, after investigating the various weather strips on the market, has had 21 schools equipped with Chamberlin Metal Weather Strips. The new Post Office building now being completed in Calgary is being similarly equipped with Chamberlin window protection; also Lethbridge schools.

After consulting with the Indian Agent and Rev. Principal, I phoned Mr. Stanley Ford, the Calgary representative of the Chamberlin line, and he came to the school for the purpose of seeing for himself the existing conditions, and to prepare an estimate for installing the Chamberlin protection on the windows and doors of Old Suns School. Mr. Ford was asked to submit alternative tenders, one for equipping all the windows and outside doors; and one for equipping part only, the idea in the latter case to give protection where the access of dust is the worst, with a view to the rest being done later. It will be noted that for complete protection the quotation is $95.00; and for partial protection where the conditions are the worst, the quotation is $545.00, the expectation being that the cost of the complete protection might be deferred to another year, if necessary. Now that the maximum shrinkage has taken place, I should prefer seeing the complete job done while the workmen are there, if the necessary funds are available, and if the Chamberlin proposals meet with the Department's endorsement.

I enclose correspondence and tenders on the Chamberlin line submitted by Mr. Ford for the consideration of the Department. The quotations are slightly less than I expected (a most unusual event) and I believe that the proposed protection would prove efficacious in removing what is at times an almost unbearable condition, or at any rate in very greatly ameliorating it. Mr. Ford will guarantee the Chamberlin protection to keep out 90% of the dust. There are other lines of window strips on the market, but I do not care to recommend costly experiments.

Should the Department sanction proceeding with this proposed installation, the Rev. Principal would like the work to be done during the approaching school vacation.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

July 6, 1931.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT

There has been considerable correspondence concerning dust getting in through the windows and doors at the Old Sun Indian Residential School. The southern Alberta climate is dry and hot and perhaps there is a bit more shrinkage than usual. It also appears that the Old Sun School is in a particularly dusty section.

Dr. Westgate is urging weather stripping for the windows and doors. Mr. Gardner Smith, at the request of the Department, made an inspection and he believes it advisable to improve conditions at this school. Mr. Stanley Ford, of Calgary, who is favourably mentioned in your memorandum of the 26th ultimo, has quoted $695 for a complete job and $645 for weather stripping for the most exposed parts of the building.

No funds were provided for this purpose and the Miscellaneous item in the Indian Education Vote has but $3,000 unassigned. What are your instructions?

Russell Brier
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I wonder if you can help me to get some paint for the school right away. As you may remember all our walls are bare plaster and the playrooms, lavatories and toilets are in an awful condition because every mark will show in spite of all our efforts to get them off.

During the holidays, I would like to get those rooms, at least, properly painted. Both Mr. Gooderham and Mr. Christiansen agreed that I should do these together with various other little jobs around the building, but there is a week of the holidays over and no word of authority to go ahead.

I know that the present retrenchment on the part of Government is making things very difficult, and I expect this is why everything is so badly held up. If, however, I could get just a little, so that we might do the most necessary parts, it would help considerably.

I originally asked for $100 for paint for this year, and I need all of that, but I can wait for half of it until after the holidays, if it is necessary. Unfortunately I cannot hope for much success in painting such things as lavatories and playrooms after the children get back, that is why I am in such a desperate hurry to get on with it.

I think everything is going tolerably well at the school but it isn't by any means what I want it to be yet.

With kindest regards,
Yours very sincerely,

Sgd. John W. House, Principal

Dear Sir:

After the experience of last Monday's dust storm, I am of the opinion that we made a mistake in not including the main entrance doors of this school in our estimate for weatherstrip.

These doors, having vestibules, were not considered necessary at the time, so were omitted, as you will note by referring to your office copy. We are now convinced that they should have been included. I would also like to state that the plans did not indicate how the transom windows over the fire-escape doors and chapel windows were set in place. These are all movable instead of being fixed as is usually the case in buildings of this type.

These transoms and entrance doors should most certainly be weatherstripped and I beg to quote you the sum of Forty Dollars ($40.00) for this extra work.

I have also been asked by Mr. House to quote you to equip the Engineer's house, and beg to say that it would cost for all outside windows and doors, the sum of Fifty Dollars ($50.00) not including basement windows.

Respectfully submitted,

Signed: Stanley Ford.

Dear Sir:-

Report on explosion of hot water Service Heating Element, Old Sun School.

In compliance with your request, I have investigated the explosion examined the exploded element, upon which I submit to you the following report:-

The heating element which exploded consisted of a Pease Boiler constructed of cast iron for the purpose of low pressure (not over 10 lbs) heating, such heating applies to radiators etc. This type of boiler was not intended for the purpose of a hot water service heater, in as much that it was designed for not over 10 lbs. whereas all hot water services require at least 40 lbs in the installation referred to a pressure of 60 lbs. is required.

I examined and tested the safety valve which operated satisfactory at 63 lbs pressure.

I examined the parts of the element broken by the explosion and found the casting very irregular varying in thickness from 1/2 in to 5/16" the cast iron stays in head not bonded to the inside casing, this being the weakest part of the element.

I find the explosion was not due to neglect in attendance but due to the heating element not being of proper strength to withstand the pressure of the system.

I would suggest that it was very fortunate the explosion occurred during the night, in as much the exploded element is located in the boiler room near a much used corridor during the day, in which was emptied the contents of the boiling water of some 500 gallons from the storage tank.

I would recommend a steel heater be installed having an ample number of hand holes to facilitate the cleaning out. Such heaters have a much longer life than a cast iron heater and use less fuel.

Also have the safety valve placed direct on the heater not in a remote position as at present.

I am yours very truly

(Signed) A. W. Dick
Gleichen, Alta.
December 28th 1931.

Dear Sir:

The hot water service heating element at Old Sun School was broken by an explosion during the early hours of December 13th. Fortunately, no one was near when the explosion took place. The Principal reported the matter later on in the day and it was decided to call in the boiler Inspector for the Province of Alberta and have him examine and report. He made his inspection on the 14th and a copy of his report is submitted herewith.

There is nothing further to be said, except of course, that this institution must have a replacement as early as possible.

Awaiting your instructions.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, January 4, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo enclosing copy of the report of the Provincial Inspector of Boilers on the explosion of the hot water service heating element in the Old Sun Indian Residential School. It is noted that the Inspector did not find the explosion due to neglect in attendance but owing to the heating element not being of proper strength to stand the pressure of the system.

As it is necessary that replacement be made, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and installation of a steel heater having an ample number of head holes to facilitate the cleaning out. Proper safety appliances should be installed on both heater and storage tank, and the installation inspected by the Provincial Boiler Inspector before the heater is used. You have not stated the cost of supplying and installing the new heater. I have to request that you will see that the total cost of this work is kept down to the lowest possible point. After same has been satisfactorily installed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

The Department by their circular l-1-5 dated February 5th.lay down a rule that all fire escape doors and the approaches to them must be left unsealed. Our Commission have the same rule.

None of us doubt the wisdom of such a regulation but there are certain difficulties accompanying the carrying out of it that, in this school, are of a serious nature.

We have already had an attempt by an outside Indian to gain admission to the Senior Girls' dormitory and have had our store room entered with intention to steal.

Our fire escape doors enter rooms as follows:
Two open directly into the Junior dormitories on the top floor. On the Senior floor, the girls' escape goes through a Staff bedroom and out to the stair. On the boys' side, the escape is opening from what we call our "bale room". It is a store room for all our clothing, bedding etc. In order to have this escape open we have to leave one door open to the boys inside, and another to the outside Indians. We have no other room we can change into a bale room, so we cannot avoid this. On the main floor one escape goes through the Matron's bedroom and the other through the boys' club room.

Now as these rooms are in such places that they cannot be continually under supervision, we shall have to have some means of knowing when the fire escape doors and that to the bale room are opened. I have investigated the ways of doing this and think that a burglar proof system should be installed, such as was explained to us by Mr.Cole. The cost of this would be approximately $100.00.

Would you please take this up with the Department at your earliest convenience.

Yours very sincerely,

GIGNED: John W.House
Principal.
Dear Sir:

I attach hereto a letter from the Principal of Old Sun Residential School relative to Fire Escapes and Protection.

Fire escapes at this institution are situated so that access to private quarters and to store rooms is unavoidable. It is not reasonable to expect doors leading in or out of these rooms to be left unlocked. The suggested burglar alarm system will solve the problem and will be further protection against illicit entry into dormitories.

The cost is based on wholesale prices submitted by the Canadian General Electric Company of Calgary plus cost of installation. If the Department has funds to install such a system in this school, I believe the expenditure is justified. Your reply will be awaited with interest.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, March 2, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, enclosing copy of a communication which you received from the Principal of the Old Sun Indian Residential School regarding the installing of a burglar proof system on the doors leading to the fire escapes.

In reply I have to say that it is considered the system suggested by the Principal is too expensive. Where it is necessary to have the exits leading to the fire escapes locked from the outside, it is thought that a suitable door lock could be installed - one where the outside door lock refuses to turn the lock and the inside one opens freely. There are comparatively inexpensive sets of this kind on the market - for example, a lock of the Yale type. It is thought this would be less expensive and just as suitable as an electric alarm bell. Could not a lock of this type be installed, which would prevent access to the school by way of the fire escapes? The school authorities should be able to arrange that the pupils would not leave the school by the fire escapes, except in case of fire or during fire drill.
