Dear Ir Gooderham,

In reference to our conversation re the possibility of some cheaper method of making our fire exits safe from the outside, I beg to state that in my opinion the only satisfactory protection is by the Alarm system outlined in my letter to you of the 24th Ult.

As you know I am desirous of eliminating as much expense as possible these days, but where the safety and wellbeing of the children under my care are at stake it is not right to risk them for the sake of saving a few dollars. The suggestion of the Department, that locks which will only open from the inside of our fire escape doors, is not any more protection than the catches we have already installed, and has the disadvantage of being more complicated for little children. Any expense on an installation of that kind would be wasted.

The difficulty of the whole situation lies in this. Being right on the Reserve, with numbers of young men looking for something to do all around us, there is nothing to prevent one of my children being intimidated by them and getting up in the middle of the night and admitting as many as like to come. Once inside the whole school is open to them. The first thing I know I shall find some of my big girls pregnant and then the damage is done. It isn't fair to take a girl away from her parents and make her sleep in dormitories that are unsafe from outside or even our inside boys. To imagine that any school management can prevent such a thing happening when doors are at the mercy of Indian Children is absolutely unreasonable. I wouldn't have one of my own girls in a school where such a condition existed and neither would any other father. Since we have already had evidence of the desire of outside boys to get into our girls even with locked doors, our fears are by no means groundless.

Then, on two floors the fire exits are through our store room and staff bedrooms. The latter are alright, but having to have both entrances of the Store room at the mercy of anyone is surely not businesslike. This cannot be altered, because I have no other room available as a store room.

Now I think that unprotected doors in a school of this description, where everything is as fireproof as possible, is liable to result in more harm to the children than locked fire escapes. Our Fire protection and drill is fairly efficient, so that even with locked doors the chances of children being damaged in case of fire, are very remote; but the possibility of immorality and theft are at a maximum, unlocked doors that are not properly protected.
If the Department is not willing to send $166.00 in a system of protection which will be adequate, there is the alternative of withdrawing their ruling about locked fire escapes and leave that question to my own common sense. I would say that the doors were open because it is better to be prepared when children's lives are at stake, but I have no doubt that we could get everyone out before fire did much damage here, under almost any condition.

It seems as though there is no halfway house in this question; it is a matter of either doing the thing properly or leaving it alone. The matter of saving a few dollars should not enter into the consideration when the price of saving is either the lives or morality of children.

Yours very sincerely

Dear Sir:

Re Voucher No. 367

I enclose herewith Voucher #367 in favour of L. Michael of Glenchen, for the sum of $153.65 for repairs to the pumping plant at Old Sun Residential School.

As I reported to you previously, the deep-seated pumping plant at this institution broke down on Sunday, October 2nd, and in a few hours no water was available for the school. I immediately secured the services of Mr. L. Michael and on inspection he found that the repairs would take some time to effect. In the meantime the school was carrying water in limited quantities, of course, from the barn well. A large sprocket wheel was broken and this had to be taken to Calgary and electrically welded because a new wheel could only be secured in the United States, and this would take at least one month. So far, the welding has held. It was also necessary to get a new silent chain as the one in use had stretched and could not be repaired.

I draw all this to your attention because the Department has not yet been advised, and recent letters and circulars emphatically state that emergency expenditures must be reported immediately. This pump has been a continual source of trouble. I believe it is required to lift too great a weight of water at each stroke as it is equipped with a 3/4" pipe. The cause of the trouble has not yet been definitely ascertained. Fluctuations in voltage in the power line were suspected and the Calgary Power Company installed a volt meter to check this up. Whatever the cause, the pump had to be repaired as quickly as possible and Mr. Michael had done good work and his account is less than I expected.

I also attach Crane's account for material supplied and you will note that L. Michael has charged less than Crane. It will be appreciated if you will forward this voucher to Ottawa and return Michael's account with Crane.

Dear Sir:

The hot water boiler at Old Sun Residential School has sprung a leak in two of the tubes and cannot be used. I have instructed Mr. Michael to give me a report on necessary repairs and he informs me that it may be necessary to purchase two new tubes in order to place the boiler in working order and the cost should not exceed $25.00. I would therefore ask for authority to proceed with the repairs.

Lepper Co Ltd of Calgary and I wrote this Company explaining the matter and asked them if this trouble was due to faulty installation and if they would consider making the necessary repairs at no cost to the Department. They are not prepared to do this and they claim that the leak may be due to peculiarities in the water, probably lime, and that the deposit will increase very rapidly in another year or so. INSPECTOR CHRISTIANSON'S REPORT ON OLD SUN'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL IN THE BLACKFOOT AGENCY:

Dear Doctor McGill;

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Old Sun's School which I made on the 19th, instant, during my recent visit to the Blackfoot Agency.

There were 89 children present,—50 boys and 39 girls — which number is two in excess of the total enrolment.

I spent all afternoon between the two classrooms of the school, and in my opinion, both teachers are very efficient in their work and are obtaining splendid results. Mr. Gooderham, the Agent, was with me, and we were both of the opinion that the children were responding well, taking into consideration that all the older children spend so much time out of the classroom.

HEALTH:

The children presented a well-kept appearance, and they are evidently being well fed and cared for in every way. I checked up on the amount of milk they were receiving as well as other food, and they are receiving an abundance of everything. Seventeen cows were being milked, and at the present time they are getting an average of 350 gallons of milk per month. This supply is sufficient to provide all the milk required for the children as
OLD SUN'S SCHOOL (Continued),—

Health (Cont'd),—

well as butter, which they have on the table at all meals.

I checked over the clothing supply and found that they are well provided with changes of apparel.

TRAINING OUTSIDE OF CLASSROOM WORK:

I questioned the cook, girls' matron, &c., as to what instructions the girls were receiving in the way of cooking and other household work. I saw the girls at work doing cooking, sewing, ironing, &c., and must say they were doing very nicely. In the summer they are taught milking, but the boys do this during the rest of the year.

The boys at this institution do all the outside work. I have mentioned that they do most of the milking, and besides this they do practically all the work on the land as well as the general chores. One thing, however, that is certainly needed here is a work shop of some kind. No instructions in blacksmithing or carpentering can be given to the boys as they have no place to work. I wonder whether it would not be to the advantage of the Indians to build work shops at the two schools in this Agency out of Band Funds.—I am quite sure that the Indians would readily agree to have this done, but I am merely putting this in the form of a suggestion.

BUILDING:

The school itself, of course, is new, and in first class shape. It is evident that the best of care is being taken of the entire building and equipment. During the present fiscal year the following painting has been done on the interior...
OLD SUN'S SCHOOL (Continued),-

Building (Cont'd),-

of the school by the staff and boys; the Department furnishing the paint: The corridor on the ground floor, bakery, staff dining room and pantry; Children's dining room, Principal's dining room and playroom.

The Principal also informed that they still have some paint on hand and the matter of painting would be gone on with in the spring. This is a step in the right direction, as the boys are thus taught how to do this kind of work, and the building is kept looking well at a very small cost.

FARMING:

This school has about 1240 acres of land. They have 200 acres under cultivation and out of this acreage 60 were seeded down to grass. No wheat was threshed, but 1000 bushels of oats and 500 bushels of barley were harvested, as well as 20 tons of green feed and 40 tons of hay.

They harvested an excellent crop of potatoes: 700 bushels, which was sufficient for all needs. Besides this they had a ton and ahalf of other garden truck.

Forty-six head of cattle are kept at the school,—mostly cows, as they sell the calves as veal, or butcher them. They also have 10 horses, and 24 pigs, but no chickens.

GENERAL:

The staff at this school consists of the Principal and two other men as well as seven women. From my observation and what I gathered while there they have a very good staff there at the present time, with the exception of the Farming Instructor, whose services, I understand, are not very satisfactory.
OLD SUN'S SCHOOL, (Continued),-
General, (Cont'd),-

Mr. House, the Principal, informed me that he intended making a change there.

Since coming to this school, Mr. House has been showing splendid results, and I have no criticism whatever to offer: I am quite sure he is doing his utmost to cope with the situation there. The condition of the farm a few years ago was very bad, and before much can be accomplished, the land has to be brought under a proper state of cultivation. Most of the land under cultivation is sandy and without irrigation will not yield very much.

The outbuildings at this institution, with the exception of the barn, are simply terrible. I will admit that I arranged for the erection of these buildings, &c., some years ago, but at that time I had only $1,000 to spend, so had to keep within that amount. The reason that the school has not been keeping chickens is that they have no chicken coop.

The machinery all seemed to be well taken care of and was all in good order except the well. The school is having some trouble with the cylinder in the well, and I am arranging with Mr. Fetterley, from the Water Power Branch, to go down on Monday to look this over.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

January 31st 1933

RE: Old Sun School Water System.

Dear Sir:

This matter has received the attention of Mr Inspector Christianson, P.A., Fetterly and mechanics in whom we have confidence and the finding is as follows:

That the existing 3/4" pipe is too large - there are 175 feet of pipe in the well and the load raised in a pipe of this size as well as pumping against 80 lbs pressure is too much for the pump causing frequent minor breakages and will ruin the plant in two or three years. The remedy is to replace the 3/4" pipe with a 3" pipe and a 3" ball valve cylinder which will be larger than the existing 3/4" spring valve cylinder. The spring valve has caused a lot of trouble.

The approximate cost of the pipe, cylinder and labour is estimated at $300.00 and we will have the 3/4" pipe for some other use.

You will no doubt receive through the Director of Water Power Bureau Mr. Fetterly's report. I may say that Mr. Fetterly made his findings when on a visit to this Agency in connection with our proposed Irrigation system for which he is now preparing plans.

Awaiting your instructions,

REPORT
on
WELL SITUATION
at
OLD SUN (C of E) INDIAN SCHOOL,
Gleichen, Alberta.
by P.A. FETTERLY
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

I. Purpose of Report.
While in Gleichen on January 30th on the proposed Irrigation Scheme for Old Sun Indian School, Mr. Christianson, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Mr. Gooderham, Indian Agent, and Mr. House, Principal, requested the writer to advise them regarding repair of the well at the School. As no extra expense or time was involved he acceded to their request.

II. Condition of the Well.
The well is 175 feet deep. The pipe is $3\frac{1}{2}$" diameter, the cylinder $3\frac{1}{4}$". The cylinder is about 20" long. The pump was the highest priced pump on the market at the time it was installed costing over $1000. It is very strongly built. The Government demanded a 1000 gallons per hour capacity. In order to obtain this capacity a $3\frac{1}{4}$" cylinder was installed. This produced a load on the pump which was too close to the ultimate factor of safety and consequently the pump is overloaded. A weight of 150 lbs. per sq. inch is exerted on the plunger. As a consequence it has been breaking down more and more frequently during the last year or more. It now ceases to function almost every week, leaving the school without water.
for several hours at a time while it is being repaired.

The valve breaks through after a short time and is made into a washer. The cylinder and rods have to be removed and repaired and are a continual source of expense.

The overloading of the pump causes different portions to break. One main 16" drive wheel broke and a new one had to be purchased in the United States, the pump having been obtained originally from Ward Love Pump Corporation of Rockford, Illinois, through Crane's Ltd. The main drive chain also broke but was welded. It did not fit properly having stretched because of jerking, and will have to be replaced ultimately at a cost of $100.

The pump does not get credit for the amount of work it does. The School uses upwards of 6000 or 7000 gallons per day when run to capacity.

The rods, 175 feet in length, have repeatedly been broken and splintered during the frequent removals and replacement for repair. Some of these will have to be replaced. At present the time of 3 men for 3 days is occupied each time it is repaired.

III. Necessary Improvements to the Well.

The present 3½" pipe should be replaced by 3" plugged and reamed pipe. The present 3½" cylinder should be replaced by a 2½" cylinder (for a 3" pipe) 3 feet long. The lower half of the cylinder can be used for a few years and then, if and when necessary, the rods can be shortened by cutting off a foot from the upper end, provided the
lower part of the cylinder becomes so worn that new leathers will not repair it. The upper half of the cylinder can then be used. This method will double the life of the cylinder without having to remove it, as 9 men days are occupied each time it is removed. The capacity of the pump will then be 750 gallons per hour instead of 1000 gallons.

The cylinder should be driven at a slower speed than the motor is capable of doing. The motor is 3 h.p. 1725 r.p.m., 21 amps at 220 volts, and 42 amps at 110 volts. By lengthening the time per day occupied in pumping, through a slower stroke, the lift of the cylinder is lengthened, and the change of weight is not so abrupt.

IV. Estimates.

175 feet plugged and reamed pipe @ 80¢ 140.00
100 feet of rods, each 20', @ 32¢ 32.00
With drop forged couplings.
5 sets couplings @ $4.50 22.50
1- Cylinder, ball valve. 3'x2¾" 60.00
Labour, 3 men, 6 days. 60.00

TOTAL. 314.50

V. Conclusion.

It is obvious from the frequent failure of the pump to function, that something more must be done than to withdraw the pipe and cylinder every week or so for repair as this is an ever recurring source of expense.
Repair has been tried and found wanting. It is therefore necessary to make a permanent improvement. The above is offered as a solution.

Calgary, Alta., February 1, 1933.

P.A. Jetterly
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

Dear Sir;-

Re Newark Fire Insurance Company Policy No. 75862
'Old Sun' School, Gleichen, Alberta

This will confirm my interview with Mr. G. A. Conley
on the afternoon of the 29th inst., with reference to the fire
insurance rate of 1.50% for three years charged under the above
mentioned policy covering the building referred to for the sum of
$40,000.

The reason for the apparently high rate is that the
building is insured for a small proportion of its value, whereas
the usual practice in rating fire resistive buildings is to make
the rate contingent upon insurance equal to at least 30% of value
being carried. On this basis the rate on this school would be
.74% for three years.

If less than 30% insurance is carried but more than
50%, the rate can be adjusted to any amount within this range,
but a certified valuation by the architect must be filed with
the Western Canada Fire Underwriters Association, and a clause
inserted in the policy providing that a stated amount of insurance
will be carried, and all losses adjusted on the basis of the agreed
amount having been carried.

I understand the cost of the building was $120,000,
and the Indians have an equity of $80,000. in it. If $80,000.
insurance was carried, representing two thirds of value, a rate of
approximately .85% could be obtained, thereby giving you double
the protection at a total cost of $650., an increase of only $80.
over the present premium on $40,000., for a further $40,000. of
insurance. These quotations are on a three year basis.

If you will forward to the undersigned at our Montreal
office, No. 500 Place d'Armes Square, a letter setting forth the
amount of insurance you propose to carry, and also the actual
value of the building exclusive of such furnishings and fixtures
as do not form part of the building, I will negotiate with the
Western Canada Fire Underwriters Association for the promulgation
of a revised rating.

Yours truly,

Inspector.

MEMORANDUM

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,-

In memorandum of January 25th last, instructions were asked as to name of person with whom fire insurance should be placed on Old Sun Residential School on the Blackfoot Indian Reserve.

The name of Mr. C. A. McKinnon of Drumheller, Alberta, was given and accordingly he was asked to place the insurance.

When this new building was erected it was necessary to use $50,000.00 of the Trust funds of the Blackfoot Indians, and this was made possible by P.C. 207, dated 29th January, 1930. To protect the Indians' equity of $50,000.00 it was considered a policy of $40,000.00 should suffice, and a policy for this amount was secured. The rate charged was 1½ which was considered too high a rate for the class of building and the matter was referred to the insurance company.

The Inspector of the insurance company, for which Mr. McKinnon is agent, was at the Department today and will place insurance for $50,000.00, full equity of the Indians, at a rate of 9½ per hundred for three years, and I would recommend that a policy for this amount be placed to cover fully the Indian equity. No insurance will be carried to cover money spent from Parliamentary Appropriation on the building. This new policy will go through the office of Mr. McKinnon.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Something must be done to improve the heating system. During the very cold weather the radiators fill with water and the circulation is poor.

Parts of the building are poorly heated and radiators may freeze and burst. The Department has on file a recommendation from the Dunham heating expert in Calgary as to how this condition may be remedied. This should be brought to the attention of the departmental architect.
Ottawa, January 11, 1935.

Sir:

I have to refer to that portion of your report for the month of December, last, on the Old Sun Indian Residential School, in which you request that something be done to improve the heating system, as, during the very cold weather, the radiators fill with water and the circulation is poor, parts of the building are poorly heated and the radiators may freeze and burst.

In this connection I would refer you to the last paragraph of official letter dated December 9, 1932. You were requested, at that time, to have the representative of the Dunham Heating Company, at Calgary, make an inspection and report. We do not appear to have on file the recommendation of the Dunham Heating Company expert. As the Durham Company are familiar with the installation of the heating equipment, they would, no doubt, be in the best position to make a report and recommendation. You may have their representative visit the school and submit a definite report, stating the cost involved in having the alterations made to the heating system in order that it will work satisfactorily in heating the entire building.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Gleichen, Alta.
but I will forward you a special bottle which you might fill with water from the well and forward it to the C. A. Dunham Company Toronto, and I will write and ask them to have the Vinsco Company make a test of this water to see if Vinsco will neutralize the effects of the soda.

You might see to it that your Engineer cleans out the boilers and changes the water as per the instructions I gave him.

Now that you have a twenty-four hour Electric Service, it would be a good investment to install an Electric Condensation Pump, instead of the Return Trap. To make this installation, however, it also requires that the Radios in your basement shall be fitted with a small trap and the ends of the steam mains trapped through #25 Plant Traps.

The pump could be installed alongside the small pump which takes care of the Residence, and the four return pipes going into the boiler room could be brought together into one header and connected to the pump. This change would allow your system to circulate steam much quicker and at lower pressure, and a saving in fuel would result and of course more comfort to the occupants of the School. For instance, just compare the comfort in your residence with what it was before the small pump was installed.

I have figured the cost of the above changes to be approximately $375.00.

Yours very truly,

A. Walker

Dear Mr. House:

Having checked over the above plant, I have found that the trouble you have experienced in heating the boys' class-room during the cold weather, was caused by two conditions. First, priming in the boilers, and second the Return Trap being unable to return the condensation to the boilers as fast as steam condensed, and the result was that the steam mains were filled with water and it was not possible to get circulation.

I do not possess a Trane catalogue, so I am unable to give you the manufacturer's rating of your Return Trap, but comparing the size with the plan that the Dunham Company would install for a building such as yours, I find that the Dunham trap is much larger than the Trane.

Your Engineer informed me that your Return Trap (before priming was noticed), was working continually, and this is not a good feature in a Return Trap.

It is pleasing to note, however, that the heating system in the Residence which Mr. Legger changed last year, is giving you first-class service.

On testing the water in the boilers, I found that it was foaming and no doubt there is a quantity of oil in the boilers, as the water from the well appeared to be all right under a test.

18.1.35 - There is foaming in the boiler now.

This has been corrected.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
PB CALGARY, ALTA., January 25th, 1935.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Old Sun Indian Residential School on the Blackfoot Reserve. In making this inspection I went over buildings and equipment, machinery, etc., and in general enquired into the management of this institution.

I found there were 88 children on the register: 83 present and 5 were at the hospital as T.B. patients.

HEALTH:

The health of the children at the school seems to be good: There was no sickness of any kind at the time of my visit although a few children were under observation for T.B. and these children are given a rest period every afternoon.

I checked over the clothing supplied to the children and found that this was ample: Every child has three or four changes of clothing, and they are well dressed. I learned from the Principal that their method

Doctor Harold W. McGill, - of -

Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA.
Health. (Continued).—

of providing the clothing is as follows: Until the children are 12 years of age, the supply of clothing is taken care of by the ladies of the Anglican Church in Toronto. They are made up there and forwarded to the school. When the children have reached the age of 12 years, their clothing is supplied by the Commission who purchase most of it in Winnipeg.

TRAINING OUTSIDE OF CLASSROOM WORK:—

Besides their academic instruction the children follow the general routine in vogue in practically every Indian boarding school. When the girls graduate they are fairly well fitted to look after their own homes as they are taught sewing, cooking, and general household science. They do the milking during the summer time and are taught how to make butter. The boys do the milking during the winter. I was there while they were milking, and was telling them that I hoped they would continue to do this after they left school.

In addition to this, the older boys are taken by the Principal every afternoon, for about two hours, to the carpenter shop where they are taught to do a certain amount of carpenter work. They are also taught by the Farming Instructor to repair machinery, &c. The work on the land, such as cultivating, &c., is all done by the boys attending the school.
FARMING:

The farming operations at the school have not been very successful on account of the drought. They only threshed 490 bushels of oats last fall and the balance of the crop was cut for feed. They had 7 tons of potatoes and about a ton and a half of turnips and some other small garden truck.

The only cattle kept at the school are cows and heifers, and they have 41 head at the present time and as a rule they have 15 or 20 cows milking. At the time of my visit they were milking 17. A register is kept of the quantity of milk that comes into the school every day and in checking it over I found that there are approximately 700 gallons of milk produced each month and the average amount of butter made per month is about 190 pounds. Both milk and butter are used by the Staff and the children of the school. I am quite sure the Department will see that the children here are getting all the milk they can drink; they also get butter with most of their meals.

BUILDINGS AND EQUIPMENT:

The school building itself is in a first class state of repair: The Department have supplied a small quantity of paint each year which has helped to keep the interior of the school looking bright and clean. The painting is done by the staff and the older boys. There is a lack of cupboard space in the dormitories.
Buildings & Equipment, (Continued),—

The only out-building worth mentioning is the barn. This building is in good shape and is kept very clean and tidy. The exterior, however, is badly weather-beaten and the paint is practically all worn off. As soon as arrangements can be made it should certainly be painted to preserve both the shingles and the siding. There is a silo attached to the barn, and it has been used regularly. It is now rotting, and I believe it is beyond repair; High winds have caused it to shift on the foundation and it is leaning to one side. The other out-buildings are not very good, and if my memory serves me correctly they were all put up for less than $1000.00; but they are answering the purpose for the present, at least. As I have mentioned on several previous occasions, this school requires a chicken-house, and this should be provided.

As this school is connected with the hydro-electric, we have no expensive machinery here, with the exception of a few motors. The only machinery is a low-pressure boiler which furnishes the hot water to the school, and a high-pressure boiler for the laundry. I had a talk with the fireman who also handles the boilers and motors, and as far as I could ascertain, he has the necessary papers to look after a high-pressure boiler. He seems to keep the machinery in good working order.
Buildings & Equipment, (Continued),-

The same applies to the heating plant which is in good order except that more water gets into the radiators than steam, evidently on account of faulty circulation. This is not noticeable when the weather is mild, but during this cold spell it has caused some trouble. I shall leave this matter stand as it has already been taken up by the Agent and reported on by Mr. Alex. Walker, one of the best heating engineers in this part of the country.

The school also had some trouble a few days before my visit with the school well, but it had been repaired and they were getting an abundance of water. The well that supplies the water for the school cattle needs cleaning out. At the present time it is only sending a very small stream through the pipe. I had a talk with Mr. Michael from Gleichen, who looks after matters of this kind for the school and the Agency, and he advised me that he thought a new cylinder was necessary for the well.

GENERAL:-

As far as I could ascertain this school is very well conducted and has an efficient staff; For some years I was not satisfied with the different Farming Instructors they had employed, but the present man seems to be giving good satisfaction, and Mr. Gooderham informed me that he thought he was an exceptionally good man — the best Farming Instructor they had ever had there.
General, (Continued),—

I examined the fire equipment and learned that the fire extinguishers had recently been refilled. There are six rubber fire hose in the building and these have become useless as they are rotting and the water comes through the walls of the hose when the pressure is turned on. Therefore six rubber hose, 50-ft. lengths, should be supplied. Also reels of the round type, as the present one are those in which you fold the hose back and forth and lie it flat in the rack and this has been the cause of ruining the present hose. Although I am explaining these matters in the report, I shall take the requirements of the school up in a special letter so that they may be more easily dealt with.

There is a skating rink at the school and all the children are supplied with skates. They also play hockey and play with teams from the local towns around there.

The staff of this institution consists of the Rev. Mr. House, Principal, the Fireman and Farming Instructor, and 7 lady employees; a total of 10. From personal observation I would say that the management of this institution is very satisfactory, and Mr. House is considered a fairly efficient Principal. The feeling between the Indians and the School is all that could be desired.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

BUILDINGS & EQUIPMENT:

The only outbuilding worth mentioning is the barn. This building is in good shape and is kept very clean and tidy. Dear Sir:

I have to advise you that during the month of January the pumping plant at Old Sun School gave a great deal of trouble. This commenced on the 4th when there was no water. The pipe was pulled and the lower valve was found to be stuck. This condition was repeated every few days until we had our local lumber made 15 trips to the school and pulled the pipe completely out 3 times and partially pulled it several times. The weather was subzero until the 15th when it again failed to run water. Mr. Michael pulled everything out on that date and made changes in the lower valve believing it would help. The tremendous suction and force of this pump apparently unloosened it again and there was no water on the 30th.

We concluded that the well was drying up and would not stand continuous pumping so made arrangements with the Principal to shut it off at night. Even on part time it has failed again, so today, we are pulling everything again and will have the lower valve (electrically welded). If the pump then fails, and there is no water, I am afraid we are beaten. We can only conclude that the well is going dry. We hope not, since there is no well to replace it except one in the barn and the water is not very good.

What has already been done means a big labour A/C. Before the well is not drying up but it is possible since there has been so little precipitation during the past two years. The Town of Gleichen had similar trouble in 1894 and a second well had to be drilled. We must hope for the best.

Preliminary Report
on
Well Situation
at
Old Sun Indian School,
Gleichen, Alberta,
by P.A. Fetterly.

1. Purpose of Report.

Mr. G. Gooderham, Indian Agent, of Blackfoot Reserve, Gleichen, Alberta, phoned this office on Feb. 6, stating that the well at Old Sun School was failing. He stated that he had written to the Indian Department at Ottawa about Feb. 1 on the matter but that as some days would elapse before our Calgary Office would receive instructions, and since immediate action seemed necessary, he wished to have the writer investigate immediately. He stated that no expenses would be needed on the part of this office as he would supply gas, meals, etc.

The writer, after consultation with Mr. Hoover, proceeded to Gleichen on Feb. 7. He interviewed Mr. Michel, Gleichen plumber, who has been attempting to rehabilitate the well; Mr. Gooderham and Rev. Mr. House, Principal of the School.

2. Result of Investigation

(a) Former Activities

Reference to a report by the writer dated
Feb. 2, 1933, will indicate that the original well contained a 3½" pipe and 3½" cylinder, installed in 1930. The pipe and cylinder were found to be too large, causing breakages, the load being too heavy for the plant. Consequently a 3" pipe and 2¾" cylinder were installed. This installation worked efficiently, until about Dec. 25, 1934. Trouble has occurred every day since then, a period of over six weeks.

(b) Primary Cause.

The primary cause of the trouble appears to be the lowering of the water table; in other words, the supply of water is lessening, the pump is removing water faster than it comes into the well. Every well in the vicinity of Gleichen has lessened considerably, including the two town wells during the last year.

(c) Behaviour of Well.

The trouble began about Christmas. The pump activates for several hours. It then ceases to yield water. The plumber from Gleichen, Mr. Michel, then goes to the school (one mile south), disconnects the working head, and raises the rods and plunger a few inches in the cylinder (working barrel) by means of a chain and block which he installed in the pump house. After the first release the whole string jumps a foot, apparently releasing air. It then settles down and he reconnects everything. The pump will then activate properly for the rest of the day. Next morning he repeats the operation. Since Christmas he has had to do this every day except two days.
The writer tested the capacity of the well on Feb.7,1935. The well was idle for about half an hour while being disconnected and until an outside discharge pipe was connected. The performance was as follows:

| Time   | Flow Rate |
|--------|-----------|
| 3:35 p.m. | 7½ gal. per minute |
| 3:40 "    | 5½ "       |
| 3:50 "    | 5½ "       |
| 4:30 "    | 5½ "       |
| 5:10 "    | 5-1/8 "    |

(d) Mr. Michel's Experiences.

Mr. Michel states that it never falls below 5 gal. per minute. He thinks that while idle the water rises 29' in the 8" casing of this 175' well. Then for a few minutes it pumps to full capacity (7½ gal.) per minute. Then the water is being pumped out faster than it comes in and the cylinder "sucks" air. This air stays in the cylinder and at last becomes so compressed that water is prevented from coming in through the lower valve. By disconnecting the working head and raising the rods and plunger - supposedly to a point just above the cylinder, the air is released and works efficiently as before until sufficient air accumulates to prevent ingress of water. In other words the cylinder becomes air-locked. It is known that so much air enters the pressure tank that the regular air-compressor is not used at all. On the contrary air is let out of the pressure tank for half a day at a time through the stop-cock on the glass gauge because...
so much compressed air comes in with the water. It was noticed that the water from the discharge pipe yesterday was continuously full of tiny air bubbles.

Mr. Michel states that in 18 years' experience around Gleichen with wells he has never met this particular type of difficulty.

(e) Mr. Joe Maughan of Calgary, Well Driller.

Mr. Maughan, who rehabilitated the well at Sacred Heart Indian School last year, was interviewed today on the matter. The action was described to him. His opinion was that the length of pipe under the cylinder was too long or too short. He thinks that a vacuum is formed in the cylinder instead of compressed air. Thus on release the water rushes in through the bottom valve. He also thinks that an air hole ½" diameter should be drilled just under the working head to allow air to enter the casing as he thinks that a vacuum is being gradually produced in the casing. The writer visited Cranes Limited, who provided the working head. They stated that the casing does not fit tightly (air-tight) on the top of the casing.

(f) Bell and Morris.

This firm provided the Hoosier cylinder in use. Their opinion was that a length of 1½" pipe should be inserted below the cylinder (the well is 12' deeper than the pipe so that the pipe will always be below the
surface. This is an obvious partial solution, of course, and occurred to the writer yesterday.

3. Remedies

The troubles are apparently two in number, viz:- apparent misbehaviour of the cylinder as described above. The plant has a larger capacity than the well will produce under present climatic conditions. Several remedies were proposed, as follows:-

(a) Mr. Michel.

Mr. Michel wanted to replace the 3" pipe and 2½" cylinder with a 1" pipe and 5/8" cylinder. This would produce 3 gal. per minute or more, being less than the probable 4 to 5 gal. capacity of the well, and thus being on the safe side. The writer negatived this solution for the present as being too expensive after the installation of two years ago and also because it would produce only 2160 gallons per day, the requirements of the school being 6000 gallons or more. It might be added that the present working head delivers with a 12" stroke, 40 strokes per minute with a 3 h.p. motor, 0.309 gal. per stroke x 40 strokes = 12.4 U.S. gallons - 10.3 Imp. gallons. Please note that the writer's full supply test was 7½ gallons per minute. Mr. Michel then proposed another alternative. This was to leave the plant as it is, but to demount the 3 h.p. motor from the top of the working head, suspend it from the ceiling to the east of the working head, place a pulley wheel on the drive shaft of the working head, and drive with a belt. The motor would be 7' away from the working head. The belt would be 7' centre to centre of pulley wheels. The pulley
wheels would be chosen so that their ratio would be
2 to 1, i.e., change from 40 strokes to 20 or better
still 5 to 2, and so reduce the strokes to 16. The
production would then be 16 fourtieths of 10.3 gallons
or about 4 gallons per minute, which is a little less
than the apparent capacity of the well.

The latter is the more sensible solution.

Mr. Geoderham, Indian Agent, and Rev. Mr. House, Principal.

Mr. House thought that possibly another well
would have to be drilled. This is of course out of the
question until the present well proves useless. He also
was apprehensive of the fact that the 3 h.p. motor on
the working head was only doing a portion of this work and
so he was using twice as much electrical energy as he
needed to activate the pump. The writer interviewed the
Canadian General Electric on this point. They stated that
if a 3 h.p. motor was called on to do, say, 1½ h.p. of work,
then the electrical energy was only about 1½ or 2½ more
than 1½ h.p. In other words the energy used is directly
proportionate to the load regardless of the h.p. of the
motor. Mr. House also complained that the power (Calgary
Power Company's lines) fails for two weeks at a time
occasionally, and after every thunder storm. At these times
they have to haul water by team. He would like to have an
auxiliary gas engine to connect up with the working head
for use in time of failure of power. His point is well
taken.

He has a well under the stables motivated
by a 3 h.p. motor. This well has been condemned for human consumption because of location. He objected to the use of a 3 h.p. motor here also as the load is much less than capacity. This well produces 3 gal. per minute by test yesterday. However his point is not well taken in this case as the above argument appertains here also as regards cost. The total bill for power for the two wells amounts to $55 per month, according to Mr. House. He thinks this unnecessarily high, although it does not appear so to the writer, considering the rates at Gleichen nearly 100 miles away from the source of power, Ghost Dam.

Expenses are high at the school and present revenue is barely sufficient to allow them to carry on.

Mr. House would also like to have a windmill on the barn well to take care of this load. This point is also well taken as he would save considerable expense. This well has 138' of pipe, i.e., about 140' deep.

One water vein is at 65', the next is at 125' and the next at 175'. One horse power would raise 13.8 Imp. Gallons per minute to a height of 150'. Therefore 3 gal. per min. would be lifted 150' by a 10' windmill producing 3/6 h.p. in a 15 mile wind. An 8' mill would leave no factor of safety. The cost of this windmill complete would be about $150 with a tower 35' high.

(4) Conclusions.

The writer tested the well for 2 hours on Feb. 7, at the end of that time the well was still producing 5 gallons per minute. Mr. Michel and Mr. House both stated that the well
would be air-locked in the morning and would have to be temporarily rehabilitated. The writer considered waiting until morning unnecessary.

Mr. Gooderham called at the office in Calgary on Saturday morning, February 9, and stated that Mr. Michel has pulled all of the pipe four times since Christmas. These operations are gradually spoiling all of the threads and should be done as little as possible.

After discussion with Mr. Gooderham on Feb. 9 it was decided to pull the pipe on Tuesday (Monday is wash day). He will take a new cylinder with him to Gleichen, also a length of 1½" pipe. On receipt of news the writer will proceed to Gleichen on Tuesday and experiments will be carried on in an attempt to correct the difficulties.

Meanwhile the matter of an auxiliary Lister engine for the house pump and a windmill for the barn pump, together with the question of remounting the motor, can be left in abeyance. The latter problem which is involved with available supply, may be solved by the use of a 1½" pipe below the cylinder.

INTERIM REPORT
ON
WELL SITUATION
at
Old Sun Indian School,
Gleichen, Alberta,
by P.A. Fetterly.

1. Purpose of Report:
This report is submitted subsequent to
a visit to the above-named school on February 18 by
Messrs. Hoover, Wm. Maughan, Manager of the Union
Drilling and Development Co. (named "Joe" in the
preliminary report, dated February 8) and the writer.
The imminence of this visit was mentioned in the report
of February 8.

2. Result of Visit:
The matter was discussed, and the well
examined, by those mentioned above, with Mr. Michel, the
plumber at Gleichen. No decision was reached as to
whether the trouble was caused by compressed air or by
a vacuum. A most searching enquiry was made by Mr.
Maughan, than whom there is no better in the West, in
the opinion of the writer, as he has obviously made a
scientific study of these matters, being a theoretical
as well as a practical well man.

His suggestion, after canvassing the matter
thoroughly was as follows:

The well is 177 feet deep. The cylinder
is 153 feet deep. The cylinder is therefore 24' from the bottom of the hole. Under the cylinder is a 3" pipe, a continuation of the main 3" pipe, 18' long in which 1/4" holes were drilled by Michel below a point 12' below the cylinder. In other words, the last 6' were drilled with 1/4" holes close together. This is, then, virtually a screen. The bottom of this pipe is plugged and would be 12' from the bottom of the hole.

Mr. Maughan suggested that the cylinder be lowered several feet and a short piece of perforated pipe be placed below the cylinder. The clearance between the bottom of pipe and bottom of hole need be only 2 or 3 feet. He thought that the automatic switch, whose limits as to minimum and maximum pressure are now 25 and 55 lbs., should be 30 lbs. and 40 lbs. respectively. This would prevent the present wide spread of pressures. He suggested that the mounting of the motor or change of gearing from 40 strokes per minute to 16 or 20 be left for the present. He naturally will not guarantee that this will cure the trouble as the cause is not yet certain. However, in answer to this suggestion the following material has been ordered for immediate delivery:

1 length (18' or 20') of 3" plugged and reamed pipe.
2 - 20' lengths 1-5/8" Octagonal wooden pump rods with 3/4" Blacksmith couplings attached.

The Crane Co., who supplied the working head and automatic switch, state that the switch need not be replaced as the present one may be adjusted.
3.

3. Further Developments.

Since writing the above it has occurred to the writer that the trouble may be caused by natural gas, i.e., that gas in some way became incorporated with the underground water about Christmas time. If that be the case, then the gaseous substance pumped into the pressure tank would be natural gas, not air. It would also follow that gas would be present in the cylinder, instead of air. In that case the accumulations over night in the pipe would be gas settling from the water and rising as far as possible, i.e., to the cylinder. This is rather a startling idea for several more or less obvious reasons.

No test was made of the nature of the gas in the water - the fine bubbles are easily noted in the free water immediately after pumping - either yesterday or during the last visit as air only was considered to be present. However one of the staff mentioned that a distinct odour of "coal oil" was noted in a pitcher of water standing over night but little attention was paid to this information at the time.

This new aspect of the case should and will be examined as soon as possible.

Mr. Michel is ready to attempt anything as he has reached the limit of his knowledge. Incidentally, he mentioned that when the screw valve in the supply pipe to the pressure tank, about 2' from the working head, is unscrewed, the gas - with little or no water -
shoots into the air, and would drive the 1 lb. screw cap 10' into the air if he allowed it. Gas is therefore present in this pipe at high pressure after pumping all day and allowing to stand all night, instead of water.

You will be advised of further developments.

Engineer-In-Charge.

P.A. Gettery
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

Sir:

Re Old Sun's School at Gleichen:

The sum of $500.00 has been authorized for the hen-house at this school. When Mr. Christianson, Mr. Gooderham and myself were there yesterday, we found that the material for the hen-house will amount to approximately $650.00. This means about $150.00 more than already authorized. I thought it advisable to have the work go ahead, so I authorized the additional expenditure in this regard. The labour is being done by the School Staff.

The extractor in the laundry recently went out of commission and is being fixed. This will probably involve an expenditure of $25.00 or $30.00.

You will remember that the Principal wrote a few weeks ago requesting some manual training tools. He has a room fitted up for this purpose and as both the Inspector and the Agent consider it very advisable to go ahead, I authorized Mr. Christianson to incur an expenditure not exceeding $50.00.

Dear Sir:

The letter of Mr. Nichols, Resident Inspector at Calgary of the Newark Fire Insurance Company, of the 7th instant, addressed to you has been received. This letter has reference to Policy No. 2267 carried on the Old Sun's Boarding School Buildings.

Dear Sir:

We have gone thoroughly into the matter of supplying a starting unit for your 26" Beaver Extractor with our principals, The Canadian Laundry Machinery Co., Toronto, and they advise that the motor best wired for the type of power used, i.e., 220 volt, single phase, 60 cycle, is the wrong type for an extractor of this size, and is bound to give considerable trouble. They are of the opinion that the motor should be re-wound for three phase as this is much better for extractor duty than single phase. However, upon taking this matter up with the Calgary Power Company, they advised that this type of power cannot be supplied to Gleichen so that remedying the situation in that manner is out of the question.

We might tell you that our people in Toronto were in touch with the Lincoln Electric Co. of Toronto who supplied the motor for your extractor, but they were not in a position to supply a starting unit which they would guarantee to be free from trouble on an extractor of this size in view of the type of power being used.

It would seem, therefore, that the only thing left to do is to have the present starting unit thoroughly overhauled. This would mean having a new set of condenser units installed. We are advised by the Howell Electric Co. of Howell Michigan, who supplied the starting unit, that a new type of condenser unit is now being used to replace the ones with which your starting unit is equipped, and they state that the new type have given much better satisfaction. Since there are only four of the new type compared with eight of the old type, it is reasonable to expect that the new units will give greater satisfaction.

The fact that your starting unit has been moved to a more suitable location should also materially increase the efficiency of the starting unit, and should further add to its length of service.
With regard to the cost of overhauling the present Starting Unit. If you will have your engineer dismantle the Unit and send to us at Calgary, we will have it thoroughly overhauled, equipped with new condenser units, returned to Gleichen and installed for $145.00.

We trust this gives you all the information you require, and assuring you of our desire to serve you whenever possible.

Yours very truly,

STANLEY BROCK LIMITED.

- Shop for manual training: $3000.00

I wish to point out to the Department that if there is any possible way of furnishing $750.00 to build a pig pen I would strongly recommend this: We have a make-shift affair which is really not fit for use, and unless a piggery is built we will have to stop raising pigs at this school.

Regarding the brick wainscotting for the boys' play-room, they can do without this for another year. I will admit it should be done: Mr. Orr went over the school in the winter time and he is familiar with what is required. The cement walks around the school are also required and any amount that can be allowed will be appreciated. The paint for the interior is also required. We could cut this down to $100 or $125. The cupboards are required, but the school can do without these for the present. The windmill for the barn would, of course, be a saving to the school as they have to pump water there for about 16 hours every day, which uses up a lot of electricity. The work-shop for manual training is not absolutely essential at the present time. I trust that whatever expenditures can be allowed by the Department in connection with the above, will be authorized.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Ottawa, June 16, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your 401-11A C.E. of the 12th instant, regarding the requests from the Principal of the Old Sun Indian Residential School, arising from the estimates submitted by him to the Field Secretary of the I.R.S. Commission, last year.

In this connection I have to say that it was only possible to provide the following items in our Appropriation for this school for the current fiscal year:

- Paint for interior - $150,
- Miscellaneous repairs - $450,
- Windmill for barn pump - $200.

The Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase, from a firm on the approved list, of the paint required for the interior of the school building, not exceeding in cost the amount of $150. It is noted that it might be possible to cut this down to $100 or $125. If any saving in the amount provided can be made, I should leave a further amount for miscellaneous repairs. I would suggest, for the consideration of the Principal and yourself, that the funds provided for miscellaneous repairs be used in the purchase of cement to make walk around school and in supplying and installing cupboards. However, the amount of $450 may be utilized as decided by the Principal and yourself in carrying out the work considered most urgent, and you may arrange for the purchase of the materials.

There will be no funds this year to erect a pig-house, to complete the brick wainscoting of the boys' playroom or to provide a shop for manual training.

Regarding the windmill for the barn pump, as stated above, the sum of $200 is available for this purpose, and you may arrange for the purchase, from the best available source of supply.

Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the above authorized expenditures, which you should certify and forward in the usual manner.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Orr,

When you were at the school, I showed you the condition of the plaster in our boys play room. We have just been trying to patch it again and are finding that the metal lath is so loosened and sprung that the plaster will not stay in place. It bulges out as soon as it is finished and begins to break away. I am afraid it has reached a point where it is about impossible to fix.

I think you said that brick from the floor to the level of the windows would not be satisfactory because of the difficulty of tying it to the wall, and your suggestion was to take the plaster right out and then replaster directly upon the hollow tile wall. I am not sufficiently experienced in the art of building to know what would be best, but I do know that a plastered play room for boys is an impossible proposition from the point of view of upkeep. Could you not help us to get something to take the place of that plaster.

I notice that the plaster is now beginning to separate farther up the wall. The reason for that seems to be that the lower part is so weakened that the weight of that above is gradually pulling it from the ceiling. I am afraid the whole thing will come down if we leave it much longer.

The length of wall needing repair is 140 feet and the plaster is ruined to a height of 5 feet. That is just the outside wall and a few feet of the inside.

With kindest regards,
Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
John W. House, Principal.

SCHOOLS

I made very short visits to the schools this month. Pupils did not have holidays at Easter but got three days when interest payment was made on the 15th & 16th. All pupils look well. REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JULY 1937.

SCHOOLS

All children were on holidays but a few T.B.'s, and some older girls who remained at school till after Calgary Stampede. Gardens at both schools are irrigated and are good. Old Sun school has a good fodder crop under irrigation. At Crowfoot grain crops were poor and are out for feed; the Principal augmented this by purchasing between 30 and 40 tons of prairie hay and wheat hay from Indians. We allowed this to co-operate, but God Knows, every ton offered is needed and then it will cost $10.00 to $15.00 per ton for extra feed for Indian stock. The well at Old Suns was inspected again by an engineer of our Department. The water level is dropping and an auxiliary well is needed, I believe. The basement of this school is being repaired. The Chief's are prepared to supply nurses at the schools for the year 1937-38 on condition that they have T.B. experience, are recommended by the Medical Branch and follow the instructions of the Medical Superintendent; all of which is reasonable, I think. The time is near at hand when this should become a Departmental and not a Band obligation.

Dear Sir:

Re: Water Supply, Old Indian School,
Glenchen, Alberta.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of yours of the 3rd instant, and in which you request a further report to supplement the report following the inspection of the water supply at Glenchen by Mr. W.H. Shelson.

Some delay has been experienced in getting out the further report, due to the fact that Mr. W.H. Shelson is now on sick leave and for several weeks has been absent not only from the Banff office, but from Banff itself. As Mr. Shelson is the only engineer in the Engineering and Construction Service who has had an opportunity of looking into this question, I forwarded a copy of your letter of the 3rd instant to him and asked that - if possible - he should supplement his original report. I am quoting below from Mr. Shelson's reply to the above request, and trust this will convey all the information necessary:

"The well at the school was producing, at the time of the test on July 10th, at the rate of slightly less than 3,000 gallons per day, and under more favorable rainfall conditions had been producing between 4,000 and 4,500 gallons per day. A well near the hospital and Agency office, about three-quarters of a mile distant North from the school, is now supplying 5,000 gallons per day to the hospital office and other government buildings. While it is impossible to determine the flow that might be obtained from any new well before drilling, it was assumed that the new well would tap the same water-bearing strata that are supplying the two existing wells, as the log of wells drilled in this locality shows in general that the water-bearing strata are pierced at 65, 125, and 175 feet; therefore, if a well were drilled within approximately 100 yards of the present school well and the work properly done, it should produce at least as much as a mean of the above wells (4,000) or between 3,000 and 5,000 gallons per day. This amount, when added to the flow of the present well, should total between 6,000 and 8,000 gallons per day. The requirement of the school is at present approximately 6,000 gallons per day."

"A tentative site for a new well was selected near the residence of the farm superintendent, some 500 feet west of the present well."

July 22nd., 1937.

Dear Sir: Re: Water Supply, Old Sun Indian School
Gleichen, Alberta.

In compliance with your request of the 5th instant, Mr. Nelson inspected the water supply of the Old Sun Indian School at Gleichen, Alberta on the 16th instant.

This system consists of a cased well 177 feet deep fitted with a 3" discharge pipe and 24" Hoosier pump cylinder. A 3" pipe, 36" long, with lower end capped and 15" of perforations above cap, is attached to the lower end of the pump cylinder. The cap is three feet above the bottom of the well.

The pump is operated by a gear head connected to a 3H.P. 60 cycle, single phase 220 volt motor. On test this motor ran the pump on a ten inch stroke at the rate of 36 strokes per minute. This gives a computed pump capacity of 80 gallons per minute. A test of the capacity of the well, made February 7th, 1937, gave an average hourly supply of 150 gallons per hour. A similar test made on the 17th instant gave an average hourly flow of but 112 gallons per hour, a decrease in supply of some 38 gallons per hour. This decrease in supply is without doubt due to a general lowering of the ground water table throughout the district, caused by the greatly decreased annual precipitation of the past two or three years. The last test was made under most favourable conditions as the school has been closed for some time and therefore the daily demand on the well has been at a minimum.

In as much as the discharge of the well at present is insufficient for the needs of the school, and as climatic conditions favouring a rise of ground water and increased supply to the well may again occur soon, I would recommend that the supply of the present well be augmented by drilling a new well on a favourable site near by. This new well should be drilled to the depth of the present one and have a motor and pump capacity to deliver 4 to 5 gallons per minute. I would recommend that a pump and discharge pipe of between 1½ and 2" be selected.

The estimated cost of this work will be approximately $1200.00 as follows:

Motor and Pump..........

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Motor and pump head ........... $400.00 installed
Small pipe and fittings ...... 125.00 "
6" well casing .................. 150.00 "
Labour drilling well .......... 300.00 "
Small building to cover well .. 225.00 "

Total ........ $1200.00

It is not anticipated that any further trouble from air-locks will be experienced when both wells are in operation, as the combined flow from the two wells should be between 7,000 and 8,000 gallons per day while the maximum daily consumption at the present time being placed at 6,000 gallons per day. The "air-locks" of course occurred when the rate of supply of water to the well fell below the discharge capacity of the pump. The pump then "sucked" air, and built up an air-lock in the discharge system.

However, to prevent and relieve any further air-locks in the present well I would recommend the installation of a "cast iron automatic air bent, 1/2", for a working pressure of 1 to 30 pounds", similar to Crane's No. 984. Estimated cost $10.00. This valve should be attached to the discharge pipe and placed between the pump head outlet and the first check valve.

Faithfully yours,

(Sgd.) C.W. Walker,
Supervising Engineer.

Dear Sir:

Relying to your wire of the 3rd instant re drilling of well at Old Sun Residential School, I wish to say that I visited the school on the 4th; pupils had been back but three days and the water supply had already failed to meet the added demand, therefore, I see no alternative but to drill another well as soon as possible. The water table is not likely to rise — we must anticipate a fall and if it does, the supply will be inadequate this coming winter unless water is rationed.

I located a driller who will operate for $1.25 per foot and it is my honest opinion that the Department should spend up to $500.00 in an attempt to get water. It is possible that it may be brought in at less than 200 feet; if it is dry hole at 200 ft. I do not recommend going much deeper. The Town of Gleichen have been unsuccessful in securing water at a lower depth and this is only one mile from the school, then the Town fathers failed to get water for the Town they looked around for old wells and finally came up with one which has been flowing for many years. The idea is a good one but in the case of Old Sun's, I would recommend the use of the barn well only as a last resort. This well has not a strong flow, but seems to be steady. On analysis, we found that the water contained considerable animal matter and should not be consumed by humans. However, it might be mixed to the school and used for cooking as a last resort.

After a well is brought in it is not a big job to connect with the school when necessary. If water is located under 200 feet it will not cost $150.00 to complete the connection. First let us get the well. I may say that Mr. Betterly and Mr. Huleman were very conscientious in their investigations of the Old Sun's water situation. I believe the demand for an auxiliary supply is urgently needed.

RE: Old Sun School well

Dear Sir:

Reverting to correspondence and your wire of September last regarding a new well at Old Sun's School, you no doubt know that the services of a driller were secured in October by Mr. C.M. Walker, Engineering Branch, Banff to drill. In this, the writer assisted in finding the driller and the location.

I am pleased to report that a reasonably good well has been brought in at 185 feet and the total cost is, I understand $505.00. I have conferred with the consulting engineer Mr. Snelson, and we strongly recommend that a pumping plant be installed and pipe laid to connect with the existing water system. This well will then become the main source of water supply and the old plant the auxiliary.

The present water supply is inadequate and unreliable. We should not go into the winter depending on it alone. I understand that it will cost about $500.00 for the plant and the connections and sincerely hope you can find the funds to install it.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Water supply, Old Sun Indian Residential School, Gleichen.

A report has just been received from my Supervising Engineer in the West that the work of drilling a new well at the above point has been completed with very satisfactory results. Tests show a water supply of more than 4 gallons per minute has been obtained which, combined with the flow from the old well, will give ample supply for the needs of the school.

Our Supervising Engineer points out, however, that there is no pump or other convenient means of supplying water from the new well to the school. This matter has been discussed with the Superintendent of the School and with the Indian Agent at Gleichen and as a result our Engineer recommends that in order to avoid a shortage of water during the coming winter, the purchase of the following equipment be made:

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith the following report for the month of April 1938.

At Old Suns, the old pumping plant quit, and is not worth repairing as parts are expensive and this type is obsolete and of foreign make. There was a water shortage and on investigation I found that the water cooled engine, operating the refrigerator, took 1000 gallons of water per day to cool it and then the water ran into the sewer. Is it not wonderful economy to dig a well and put in a pumping plant, which supplies little more water than it requires to cool a 3 H.P. engine. It should be replaced of course, by an oil bath engine. To supply the bare necessities, the refrigerator is shut off part time and hose from the water cooled engine and also from the barn well, where a borrowed pressure tank is installed, augment the water supplied from the plant installed in 1937, and gives the institution sufficient for the present. The old well should be cleaned and if there is then a fairly good supply of water, a Delco plant should replace the obsolete one. This will be a summer holiday job. We ploughed some land for this school with an engine outfit, as they are low on horses. Here's hoping the church has a prosperous year and funds to equip themselves.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

RE: Old Sun's Refrigerator Plant

Dear Sir:

At the Old Sun Residential School a water cooled compressor was installed to operate the Frigidaire. This was installed when the School was erected and equipped.

Recently, one of the plants which supply water to this institution gave out and temporary measures were necessary to get sufficient to meet dire needs. Among other things, we looked at the refrigerator compressor where water was used and wasted into a drain. On a test we found that this compressor used between 900 and 1000 gallons every day. That is a terrible lot of water when it is so scarce and when the cost of power to pump it is so high. It is bad business.

I consulted Bruce Robinson Electric Ltd of Calgary Provincial Agents for Frigidaire and am advised that the water cooled compressor can be changed for an air-cooled compressor and installed for about $55.00. I beg to recommend that the change be made.

Your obedient servant,

June 1st, 1938

Dear Sir:

The Old Sun Residential School has been carrying on with a rationed supply of water since the middle of April. The old well and the plant which has been in use for some years, gave out. The cost of repairing the plant will be considerable and, in our opinion, is not justified. It is of obsolete type.

We believe the well is still good if cleaned out, and it is our recommendation that it be cleaned and if the water supply is satisfactory, that a Delco Plant be installed to replace the old plant which is little more than scrap.

The only reliable driller in these parts is Myers Rasmussen and he is prepared to clean out the well for the sum of Seventy Five Dollars. We think the well has filled in from 30' to 40' with silt and sand, and as there is a small brick building over the well, it will not be an easy job to clean it. Rasmussen's offer is reasonable. Would authority be granted to do this work?

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
EXD.

Ottawa,
June 7, 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant you may incur an expenditure not exceeding $75.00 in cleaning the well at the Old Sun's Indian Residential School. In connection with this school I may say that in the current year's appropriation an amount of $750.00 was provided for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment. Owing to the present set up of our appropriation it is practically impossible for us to exceed the amount specifically provided.

Recently we placed an order for an air-cooled compressor for the frigidaire. The approximate cost of this is $65.00 and this amount, together with the cost of cleaning the well, will have to be deducted from the amount provided. This leaves a balance of $10.00 which amount is all that we can expend during the current fiscal year at the Old Sun's School for repairs, improvements and new equipment.

You might consult the Principal and if it is necessary to expend this amount you should supply full particulars regarding what you consider is most necessary. In the event of any equipment or material being required full particulars should be given in order that the matter may be placed before our purchasing Agent.

Yours truly,

G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,

Dear Sir;-

Attention Schools section.

At the Old Suns Residential Boarding School there are three things that should be attended to right away i.e.

1. the installation of a pumping plant in the well which was recently cleaned out.
2. the repair of the hot water boiler which is leaking badly and
3. the rebuilding of the root cellar which has caved in.

In regard to the pumping plant, correspondence with you will indicate the difficulties encountered in securing sufficient water for this institution. We are now satisfied with the water supply and believe which does not pump over 3 gallons per minute will not draw too heavily on this well and will be sufficient, since a similar unit operates in a well drilled in 1937. The total supply from the two wells would be in the neighborhood of 5 gallons per minute and that is a lot of water per day. The local plumber, L. Michael, has kindly assisted us in compiling the bill of material required for this system and same is attached hereto with estimate of labor costs. Mr. Michael is the local agent for Bruce Robinson, Calgary, general agents for General Motors products.

2. Re the upright heating boiler, 50 flues are leaking badly and must be rolled and beaded. Mr. Michael has offered to do this for $25.00 and I recommend acceptance; he does finished work.

3. A root house was built some years ago from old lumber and fence posts. Most of it rotted and
saved in this year, needless to say a frost proof cellar is needed. The Principal removed the top and will require some new material to rebuild it.

There is only one Lumber yard in this district, the Crown at Gleichen. Attached is a bill of material. The cost if purchased from the Crown Lumber Company will be $52.45.

The Principal of the School has just returned from holidays and after consulting with him and keeping in mind that the appropriation for this school is limited, we ask that the foregoing be approved.

It is hoped that there will be little delay. The water plant and boiler will be needed when the school opens in September.

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, February 4, 1939.

Dear Sir,

Old Sun Residential School
Indian Affairs Branch

Cheque 5176 was issued on October 1, 1938, to T. H. Beach in payment of an insurance premium of $650.00 on the Old Sun Residential School and was charged to the Blackfoot Band Trust Account No. 137, the school being insured at $50,000, a portion of its total value.

This building was constructed by the Department of Indian Affairs in the fiscal year 1929-30 at a cost of approximately $135,000. At the time it was found that the amount set aside in the Parliamentary Appropriations of that year was not sufficient to carry the school to completion, and so under the circumstances the Blackfoot Band agreed to loan the Crown $60,000 from their Capital Funds under Section 93 of the Indian Act. The loan was approved by Order in Council 207 dated January 29, 1930, and reads in part as follows:

"The Minister states that it is proposed that this amount should be refunded to the band within the next two fiscal years in conformity with the department's policy that all cost of Indian Education should be defrayed from public funds."

To date the loan has not been repaid and reference has been made to it in various letters relating to the audit of revenue and verification of cash.

I would be pleased, however, to learn why insurance is carried on this apparently government owned building, since the Department considers the $60,000 a responsibility of the Crown. Also in the event of the destruction of the building by fire would the Band be entitled to the insurance and the repayment of the loan?

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Geo. Gonthier
Auditor General.

Charles Gansel, Esq.,
Deputy Minister,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of February 4th, I wish to advise you that the insurance carried on the old Sun Residential School, Blackfoot Reserve, was placed in 1933 for the purpose of protecting the equity of the bond in the building after the term of the loan had expired without repayment having been made and no immediate prospects of funds being available to do so.

In the event of the building being destroyed by fire, it is considered that the bond would be entitled to receive the insurance or repayment on the loan, but certainly not both.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re - Old Sun Indian Residential School

You are probably aware that when the Old Sun C. E. Residential School, on the Blackfoot reserve, Alberta, was destroyed by fire in June, 1928, it was impossible, owing to the limited appropriation set apart for the project, to rebuild at that time until the Blackfoot Indians consented to loan to the Crown $60,000 from their Interest Account to enable the work to proceed. The Department contributed $40,000 toward the construction of the new building. The present school was constructed by the Department during the fiscal year 1929-30.

The loan secured from the Blackfoot Band was approved by Order in Council 207 dated January 29, 1930, and reads in part as follows:

"The Minister states that it is proposed that this amount should be refunded to the Band within the next two fiscal years in conformity with the Department's policy that all cost of Indian Education should be defrayed from public funds".

To date this loan has not been repaid although the desirability of making repayment has come up for discussion on more than one occasion during the last two or three years. I am anxious therefore that consideration should be given this year to the desirability of providing in the supplementary estimates now under consideration the sum necessary to meet this obligation in full.

Director.

Dear Sir:

Re: Old Sun School

Roof drains on the flat tar and gravel roof of this institution have commenced to leak and will destroy plaster if not attended to immediately. There are three copper roof connections now leaking, which is due to corrosion caused by sewer gas as they are connected with the sewage system.

The cost to replace the copper connections and to repair the flashing which in recent high winds has been loosened and ripped off in places, will, according to Mr. Michael, Gleichen plumber, total $58.00.

Last year the main chimney of this institution was hit by lightning and the falling brick apparently damaged a space about 20 x 30 of the tar and gravel roof over the chapel. To re-tar and gravel will cost about $34.00.
